When you vote for a political party there is normally a glossy party manifesto to say what the party propose to bring in while in office.
In the EU such a concept is not recognised. If any party manifesto is produced the MEPs don't have the legislative or authoritative power to implement a single thing in it any more than an individual EU citizen. What we effectively vote for are rubber stamps in the shape of MEP's who give consent to policies formulated in secret meetings where the people have no say.

Interesting though this may be, it doesn't answer the central problem with the EU; it is not democratic, and indeed, why would it ever wish to reform itself. Members of the EU parliament cannot make laws; they merely reject or, more usually, rubber stamp proposals made by the unelected, unaccountable EU Commission. Why would people bother voting for MEPs if they are unable to make laws? The British government also proposes laws; however, unlike the EU commission, they are accountable to their electors via General Elections. The EU commissioners are not. That is why people who talk of reforming the EU are living in a fool's paradise; why would the unelected and unaccountable ever want to expose themselves to the tiresome task of actually fighting and winning elections? It's never going to happen.

For me, I think the argument is more that a foreign national government has more influence over your national policy than your own national government. When I spoke to people in Greece, their problem was that corporate interests in Germany had investments outside of the EU that they wanted protect, therefore Greece was artificially limited on the amount of products it is allowed to export by EU law due to Germany's influence over the union and was a major factor in their economic downturn. Also, in the matter of Ukraine how much EU members are held hostage by other (sometimes pseudo-fascist) member states in their foreign relations. I don't know the details, I'm not from Europe and won't claim to understand the situation there, but it seems wild that a free trade agreement that's supposed to reduce political barriers was expanded into an international government which increased them.

The less political power any one citizen has, the less "fair" a democratic system really becomes.
The EU is sort of maximizing this concept as very few citizens actually care to understand even the basic workings of the structure. Getting information that is relevant to the suggested "importance" of your vote is in fact seriously difficult and time consuming:
'What questions are relevant in the EU right now and for 4 years to come?' - ????
'Who are these people I get the option of voting in?' - In rare cases, you can find SOME information about this, depending who it is.
'What's the power balance like in the EU today? Is my vote actually going to be worth anything?' - ????????????
And then finally: "What do I want from the EU myself, really?" - ...And this question is the most relevant one, as most of us don't really want anything at all from this allmighty council.

So: Is the EU "fair and democratic"?
- You're battling with over 400 million potential votes to make YOURS count. - Your personal vote is like a drop of water in the ocean.
- The above statement isn't really true, as member states get a certain amount of representatives that are voted in by that state's population - However, a less relevant state with less seats voted in can practically become powerless in a council of such size, meaning that even if your vote did count for the representatives there, the representatives could very likely be absolutely useless in the position meaning that whatever choice you and vast swathes of people made for that/those seats, nothing would've changed, and whatever choice you wanted the council to have made would still have gone in the same direction.
- You've got very little relevant information that is very difficult to get hold of as well as in many cases difficult to interpret while at the same time being very indifferent about the choice to begin with.

So: The EU is anything BUT 'fair' to citizens. It shouldn't operate in the manner it does today, as the democratic power is extremely diluted to the point where ANY decision made definitely classifies an abuse of power.

Basically the EU's Politics:
You choose the President to the European Council, the Minister to the Council of the EU, and the Parliamentarians to the European Parliament. All three send for the European Comission a Commissioner of each country.
Easy right? So prepare... The European Parliament, the European Central Bank and the Council of the EU send money to the Budget and the European Court of Auditors see if they send and used adequately.
The Council of the EU, the European Council and the European Comission vote for laws and the European Court of Justice approves or reject the laws.
The Foreign Affairs Council and the European External Action Service treats about the International Relations and the European Economic and Social Commitee treats about the internal trade and jobs. For last, the European Commitee of Regions treats about the EU representations inside the countries (provincies/regions/etc).

Your assessment of the EU Parliament is extremely biased. The matters on which it can actually vote directly are few, and the topics that, in a democracy, SHOULD be under most direct democratic control actually escape its influence completely. It doesn't even have the initiative of EU regulations (it can only approve or reject one in full, and can merely make non-binding suggestions for amendments). In practice, this means that the European representatives can only give their opinion on matters that the other (non-elected) EU institutions deem worth talking about. The most central of political questions (including economic, monetary, and social issues) are almost exclusively dealt with by the Commission, and, de facto, only by a few members from key states within what is called the "trilogue", where decisions are made without any democratic transparency at all.

The state of EU democracy has best been summarized by Wolfgang Schäuble, the German finance minister, who stated that "Elections cannot be allowed to change economic policy" (see Yanis Varoufakis' book "Adults in the Room"). And given that economic policy includes monetary policy, and has a massive impact on everything else the EU does, basically any decision of importance is outside of the scope of democratic government.

Also, your claim that the EU was built to ensure peace in Europe is incomplete at best. It was thought of as a common market from the start.

This would be ok if we were just a lose alliance of states with individual currencies, managed adjustments of the exchange rates and possibly a common central bank; but since we have the Euro, we created a situation where our economies affect each other in ways that are not mutually beneficial, and those who benefit from it the most have way less incentive to reform the EU into a democratic union that actively manages the imbalances. Politicians of the major parties don’t even talk about those problems in a straightforward way or propose any solutions during elections. Worse: even minority parties who are supposed to check the government are too afraid of the EU falling apart to voice even the slightest criticism. And if you‘ve ever voted in a national and in a European election, you should be quite aware which one of the two gets a lot of attention by the media and by the people.

In the end, regardless of where you are in the world, democracy only works when you have somebody running that you believe can represent you and your political opinions. Cause in the end even if you don't win, your opinion is recorded. If you're ever at the ballot box and think "At least this option is better than the alternative" then the system has failed to present a valid representative for you, and then trying to vote strategically so the worst choice isn't selected only digs a deeper hole, since your vote now conveys that some shmuck you couldn't care about is your representative.

America's oligarchy is a disgusting example of democracy in utter disarray since it's a haphazard system created to facilitate 100k citizens, not 400 million. It starts out with a good idea, a bunch of candidates with different political agendas and platforms, whilst under the banner of one of 2 parties. Citizens find politicians who best represent them and their opinions. The 2 parties now make the executive call to erase all of that in order to put all it's money on the most likely to win, erasing the vast majority of people's opinions and striping most of them of a representative that truely conveys everything they beleive. It turns a fluid and complex bunch of opinions into a black and white "I gotta beat the other team no matter the cost" type of game. In the end the citizens still vote, so technically democracy, but just barely, since they can't really choose anything besides what colour tie the president will wear for the next 4 years.

The EU has a similar issue where it's not allowing a series of representatives to take the stage, so public opinion can be gaged properly. As such people are often forced to vote for people they don't care for to avoid a worse option in office, and since that pity appointed loser is now in charge, and thus can pick and choose all his squad mates. Now that loser can rampage to his hearts content, fucking shit up, since "it's the will of the people", which only builds hatred to your neighbours.

You need you opinions and ideals properly represented, and when the system fails to do that, and then you gotta vote anyway, it only makes people dislike the entire political system. The USA, or the EU isn't the issue, it's the fact that we continue to use outdated or backward political systems that completed strip all of the benefits of democracy out of voting.

Federal Government? Is that you?

Introduction

One of the most vital Constitutional rights of EU citizens is their right to elect and be elected in European elections. Since the founding of the European Union, it has been in everyone’s interest to make sure that the EU stays united, and acts with regard to everyone’s opinion. However, the expansion of the EU in the 2000s has led to the integration of many states which, to a great extent, still feel detached from the EU. Even in the founding Member States, citizens still feel that their votes are not enough to influence the decisions of the European Parliament.
This is closely correlated to cultural integration into the EU, and figures show that some of the basic steps towards a united EU and the enforcement of democracy are missing. For example, despite an average of 40-50% of citizens throughout the EU feeling “European” along with their own cultural ethnicity, up to 10 years ago, the majority did not know their rights as EU citizens. This result varied, with countries such as Italy, France and Greece having low percentages of citizens who know their rights, with some as few as ⁄ .Although these figures have risen, a parallel rise in Euroscepticism, the feeling of doubt towards European Integration has led to citizens demanding more from the EU. The Special Eurobarometer survey on the Future of Europe in Autumn 2020 highlighted the vast majority of citizens wanted their voices to be heard, regarding the future of the EU.
Furthermore, the feeling of being detached from the EU can also be justified when looking at the internal structure of the European Parliament. Newly-integrated states have consistently had less of an impact on decisions of the EU, something which stems from and, at the same time, causes low voter turnout in many states. If we examine the Distribution of politicians in leadership positions in the European Parliament, we can clearly see a difference between Member States,reflecting this democratic detachment. Therefore the influence and power of each Member State might not be distributed equally amongst all states. Specifically, Germany, France and Italy together have 160 officials in such positions, while Latvia, Cyprus, Slovenia, Lithuania and Croatia have 10 officials combined. It is in our best interest to let these countries, and everyone that feels democratically detached, make their voices heard as this would not only benefit them, but the EU as a whole, as we know that all of us together can achieve much more that any of us alone.

Stakeholders and measures in place

The European Commission (EC) proposes changes to the Parliament. Apart from the campaigns aimed at increasing voter turnout in most EU states such as Greece or Hungary, the Commission recently established one of the most important measures towards increasing the democratic representation of all EU citizens: The Conference on the Future of Europe. It is defined as “citizen-led series of debates and discussions”, with the goal of offering dialogue directly between citizens and the EU. Initiated by the Joint Declaration on the Conference on the Future of Europe,. The president of the European Commission, Ursula von de Leyen, says that by implementing the conference, we “invite all Europeans to speak up”. The conference will take physical and digital formats all across the EU, with one of its most important features being an online platform that is to be set, allowing citizens to submit their ideas on current affairs and issues that concern them. It is up to local authorities and governments to also organize related events and invite young people to participate. The EC along with two other stakeholders, the Council of the European Union, and the European Parliament, represented by their leaders, make up the Conference's Joint Presidency.
The Secretariat-General of the EC is composed of top-ranking officers that are elected. It supports the whole commission and oversees the coherence of its work in shaping new policies. Therefore, it is the main body responsible for making sure that all policies equally affect all member states’ needs and that they are applicable in all scenarios.
The “Europe for Citizens” initiative is a EU funding programme for “citizens to participate and engage in democracy at the EU level”.. It has funded more than 1,700 projects, with Slovakia, Hungary and Italy being some of the most funded countries for 2014-2018, showing demand to combat the low turnover in votes and participation in EU elections.
The Directorate General for Regional Policy of the Commission, is in charge of the EU’s Cohesion policy. The Cohesion Policy, aimed at establishing the harmonious development of state, has as a goal to increase democratic participation in EU matters and the decisions of the Parliament. For example, the Directorate General recently approved and funded the Youth in Action for Cohesion Policy (YACOPO) Project, which is aimed at increasing youth participation in the design and implementation of cohesion policy in the Italian region of Sardinia. The interest of the EU in involving citizens also resulted in the recent high-level conference “Engaging citizens for good governance in Cohesion Policy”, held in February 2020 in Belgium.
When considering the economic reasons behind anti-integration policies by most right-wing nationalist parties, a new stakeholder enters the conversation, the World Trade Organization. One of the main reasons countries want to leave the EU, is the policies it holds on trade. Being one of the areas the EU has exclusive competence in, the conditions for trade in each country have to adhere to EU laws, with the exchange of free trade between Member States. If a state such as Britain decides to leave the European Economic Area of the EU, would have to trade under rules set by the WTO. Many small traders and businessmen in heavily taxed countries that need to respect the laws of the EEA feel like their needs are being ignored, thus economic reasons become the driving force behind some anti-integration policies.

Key conflicts

Inclusion vs Sovereignty: There has been continuous conflict between supporters of the EU and nationalists that want the EU to be the only sovereign body that can take decisions. The issue ofEU democraticanditsdefactoroleasafederationhasbeenapparentsinceitsinception,inthe late 20th century. In the status quo, national parliaments remain the legitimate representative bodies in Europe’s transnational structure. The competences of the EU are limited to international relations, monetary currency and fundamental rights and right now, relations between EU states are considered matters of international diplomacy. However, the current model of law-making in the EU also allows for inequalities between Member States withstate governments having most control over issues that concern the people. Although it can be argued that all states democratically authorize their government to act upon their behalf, many Eurosceptics argue that their representation in the EU parliament is not sufficient to put forward their needs. A form of direct connection between the EU, the Council and the citizens might be a beneficial approach, but it also faces financial and bureaucratic restrictions.
Another similar conflict could be centralization and state authority. The European Parliament’s Europe of Freedom and Direct Democracy party, although now defunct, proved that the years a er the economic crash of 2009 were not very easy for all EU citizens. Loans were issued and taxes increased, resulting in anti-integration policies being adopted by many populist politicians across the EU. These people argued that state authority must be increased and that the EU’s plans did not equally benefit all Member States. The trend of centralization in the EU’s decision making goes against this, as the decision structure of the EU gives significant policy-making strength to institutions whose power does not come from national elections, such as the European Commission or the European Central Bank.
Many have accused the EU of being a federation, and have criticised its decisions to push Member States to give up some of their sovereign functions, mostly those in the areas linked to the single European market, including regulations for trade and competition. Moreover, many states have given up monetary policy sovereignty and are part of what we know as the Eurozone. All these measures allow for the EU to take decisions and influence the economic functions of states which has potential for many beneficial functions, but also gives critics the opportunity to accuse the EU of infringing on the states’ rights. Therefore, the current state of the EU projects some opportunities and obstacles which you, as delegates, have to discover, and avoid, respectively.

If you're an EU member wondering what the future might hold for you, I'll use some American (sorry) examples. If you empower the EU and diminish the power of the member states and their leaders, you will end up most likely with a monolithic government like that of the current United States - trending towards being one people instead of many. This means a strong central government that can do more, but is also more bitterly fought over for control of it... so don't be surprised if you choose this option that you will see a partisan, polarized EU in the future like what America currently "enjoys". The upside (sort of) is this means a more cohesive state, but EU bureaubirbs who you may not like or know at all will have more power over you, and individual freedom of the states and possibly the citizens themselves will be less than the following possibility.

However, if you vote for individual member states and heads of state to retain their power and influence, you will most likely end up with a union or coalition with strong what we call "state's rights" in the USA - which can be good or bad. Depending on how far you go with this, you can still end up with the modern USA government, or another form of government that didn't do so well... I'll get to it in a bit. State's rights in their current form means that Americans can choose on a state level if they want, say, recreational or medicinal marijuana to be legal, which I think is a good thing. However, this also means that individual states can do bad things and even the President can't do much about it, like the recent Republican efforts to "clean up voting" in the USA after Donald Trump lost the 2020 Presidential election - many having a large outcry over this attempt to make voting harder, mainly affecting Democratic voters like the poor and people of color. But partially because of state's rights, President Biden can't do much about it. Congress has to act at a national level to prevent such things, and this is unlikely given the Senate is currently split 50/50 between Trump leaning Republicans and Democrats.

If you go too far with state's rights, you end up with a Confederacy, where the states are very powerful and independent, where the central government does not hold much power at all. This was tried twice in American history - once at a national level, under the highly ineffective Articles of Confederation, which did not even give the national government to raise taxes at all if I remember correctly, and then in the American South, when states split off and formed the Confederate States of America. Due to its very nature, ignoring all industrial disparity in the war between North and South, the CSA was not a very functional state; for example, in the waning days of the war, they repeatedly requested more men and supplies for the Civil War from the member states... only for many members to refuse, saying basically "I don't want any of our Texans dying to defend a bunch of Virginians." There may be some upsides to a confederacy, but it is unlikely that either the USA or the EU will ever see this type of government ever again, given modern trends towards more state power and centralization.

A quick and easy way to make the EU more democratic is to strengthen the European Parliament. You could give it the power of legislative initiative or the power to appoint and dismiss the European Commission on its own, similar to the parliaments of member-states. The big issue with that reform, though, is that doing so will empower the EU to make and pass laws binding all EU citizens without the consent of the member-state governments.

This is what happened in the US. Originally the only part of the American federal government that was elected by the people was the House of Representatives. The Senate was elected by state legislatures and the President was elected by the Electoral College, whose members were appointed and told how to vote by the state legislatures. This gave state governments a lot of power over the federal government and kept the country largely decentralized. But after complaints from voters about the undemocratic nature of the Senate and Presidency, a series of reforms were passed in the 19th century. The President is still elected by the Electoral College, but now state governments organize elections for President and require their representatives in the College to vote with the plurality of their state's voters. The 17th Amendment to the Constitution was passed, which made Senators directly elected by the public. These reforms have made the American federal government far more democratic, but they also severely weakened the state governments. There is now no branch of the American federal government that derives its power from the state governments, which means it can pass laws without having to consult with or get approval from the states.

Now, I personally believe that, in general, the more democratic a system, the better. I much prefer today's federal government structure over the original form. But it still came at a cost to American federalism. These democratic reforms have made the federal government far more powerful at the expense of the states, which is not what the framers of the Constitution intended. I personally don't think that's a bad thing, but many Americans do. The European Union is now facing that same conundrum. Which is more important to EU citizens: making the EU more democratic or preserving the powers of the member-state governments?

The EU commission is always presented as the EU government. Problem with that is, it is patently false. They are at best the bureaucracy level of government. They have no mandate to formulate policy or make political decisions, what they do is implement decisions by the EU Council, be it those made in treaties or those at Council meetings.

E.g. the EU commission may suggest a specific trade policy, however the decision for or against it is done by the EU Council, maybe even national parliaments, not the EU Comission.

To me the problem here is that the entire anti democracy narrative agenda hinges on the complete misunderstanding how much power the EU Commission has. In essence it is a strongly curtailed body of, yes, unelected bureaucrats, that at best gets limited mandates by the EU Council while being controlled by EU parliament. They are how top level bureaucracies are being instructed by elected officials in pretty much all representative democracies. They are not the people with mandate, they are advising and then implementing what they are being told by the people with mandate.
For once the U.S is the one who figured this one out first

If every nation agrees, but say Malta, half a million people, in a union of half a billion, disagrees, and vetoes, then a vote doesn’t go through. I don’t think you’ll find many Democratic systems where 0.1% of the population can stop laws and legislation. That’s ignoring the fact that the EU body that actually has the power, the European Commission, is appointed, and that even the voting for the European Parliament, the elected chamber, saw turnout fall at every single election from 1979-2014, with an overwhelming majority not even turning up to vote for most of the last couple of decades, because it has so little meaning or influence. I am British and I voted to Remain, primarily because there is a lot of downside risk to Britain leaving the EU, poor trade deals, tariffs, trade frictions, misaligned regulatory frameworks and the like, with our main trade partner, could be very harmful, that’s without touching upon the lost soft power. With that said, the EU isn’t Democratic, not even close, and that is the crux of the problems that have persisted since its inception, it’s a Technocracy masquerading as a Democracy. The EU, formerly the EEC, had so little care for Democracy, that for decades after it was formed, it didn’t even hold these sham Elections, so that it could pretend to be a Democratic system.

As both an EU citizen and an American citizen I can say with confidence that my vote has counted far more with the European elections than in America. The American government is more or less a single party state with two factions (one being less egregious than the other, by not hating minorities) and none of our politicians represent us. They enact policies that take away rights and have extremely low approval ratings. They do nothing but give tax cuts to the rich. The country is effectively an oligarchy. It doesn’t help having an electoral college where the interests of a few states decide the elections. America feels utterly hopeless right now. With europe, I can at least vote for a left wing party. By voting green I watched my vote count. And outside of America and Europe it’s hard to imagine a place other than Europe where your vote counts more. Latin American countries? Almost all corrupt. African countries? Obviously not. Middle Eastern and Asian countries? Nope, not even close. Only Australia, New Zealand, Canada and SK & Japan strike me as countries with better representation than some of the countries in Europe. We as EU citizens don’t know how good we actually have it.

In America the views of the constituents aren’t reflected in the politicians. Half the country has no choice but to support a party that doesn’t actually change to reflect their views anymore. And it sure as hell would be a dream to be able to have your vote influence the structure of the whole government. That’s a privilege Americans don’t even have.

It is now clear that Brexit was always an attempt by the rich, such as Rupert Murdoch, to escape the 2016 EU Savings Directive, which would expose the tax details of all those hiding funds in the tax havens directly linked to the UK’s financial system: the three Crown Dependencies (e.g. including Isle of Man) and most of its Overseas Territories (e.g. including British Virgin Islands). The Directive would create strong automatic exchange of tax information laws that would expose literally trillions of hidden funds that the rich and famous avoid taxation by using the UK’s banking system to access them. The Directive was very unique, and like its predecessor, applied to all these places because, although not in the EU, the UK is directly responsible for them, and by virtue of its constitutional relationship with them, has direct access to their banking systems unlike any other country on Earth.

I say it is now clear, because the Companies Act 2006 has now been amended by the (UK Exit) Regulations, which expose exactly what was intended, such as allowing companies to avoid using auditors authorised within the EU, who are not obligated to abide by its standards against tax evasion and avoidance, including the EU Savings Directives. The many explicit amendments there make it very clear now what the intention was all along, and it makes sense when you put all the pieces together.

It was proposed in 2014 (i.e. when the referendum talk all started) and was to come into force in 2016 (i.e. when the referendum was to take place). Naturally, it was backed by MANY rich and powerful tax avoiders around the world, including the likes of Rupert Murdoch — who controls the British press — rich politicians like Boris Johnson, and NIgel Farage: who is a rich banker who worked for Crédit Lyonnaise for many years, naturally gaining many contacts ready to back him.

The majority of the European Research Group (ERG) are also very rich, using the tax havens in question to avoid paying due tax — Nigel Farage has even admitted to this. Of course there is tax planning, which many rich and famous use, but the danger here is tax evasion: which currently, the UK’s tax havens are very easy to take advantage of in order to do so; the EU Savings Directive 2016 would have exposed all their tax avoiding/evading schemes, and made them susceptible to paying UK tax to the order of trillions of pounds per year.

Those at the top of the BBC, such as Robbie Gibb, were also in on it, being wealthy and actively trying to adjust broadcasting so as to convince the public that Brexit was the right thing to vote for. Rupert Murdoch had the country in his hand, and could use his press to convince the country similarly. The rich politicians had the power to implement the result. Since all of the tax havens linked to the UK, when considered together, count for more than half of the world’s tax havens, there is no doubt that wealthy people around the world rely on their secrecy in order to avoid tax, and therefore have been backing Brexit so as to avoid being discovered by the EU Savings Directive. This is why we had a variety of very rich people coming out as in support of Brexit, including Donald Trump, although he also admitted he sees the EU as competition, and therefore inevitably would like to have the edge over it again, by seeing the UK depart, and once again seeing the USA as the world’s most powerful single market again over the EU.

The real issue though is, why didn’t anyone come clean with the truth about the cause behind Brexit? If there is a real benefit to avoiding the EU Savings Directive for the UK, in terms of money it makes through the banking system with the Crown Dependencies and Overseas Territories, then why not say so? Or is there really no benefit to it, other than to the rich and famous, who can keep avoiding paying UK tax? Although, when you consider the huge amount of tax that would become due under the EU Savings Directive, bringing billions of pounds to the UK, it is hard to see how anything could possibly counterbalance that and potentially have a greater benefit to the UK.

So the problem therefore is that they intentionally planned this together — the media, politicians, and financiers — but did not tell anyone the real reasons behind it, or that they were even working in tandem. It became pretty explicit how Nigel Farage was working with the Conservative Party ERG at the end of the show and the 2019 election, but was never explicitly mentioned, and it is only through whistleblowing MPs that we know about those complicit at the BBC, such as Robbie Gibb, who at the time, had transferred from the BBC to the Conservative Party press team, through links he had with ERG members.

This is beginning to look like a scandal more and more. The BBC should be neutral. The press should report the news for the benefit of the reader, not to ensure the rich mogul at the top keeps his billions by influencing the audience to vote for it by telling them a whole host of different reasons why they should, EXCEPT the real reason.

The British people deserve better than this. I hope the contents of the Companies Act (EU Exit) Regulations becomes more widely scrutinised, and that the people of the UK find some way of discovering truth. My only fear is that with the press entirely behind it, capable of convincing the people to do what they want them to do, for their own benefit, rather than informing them of the truth — and with politicians also readily telling their constituents they are acting to their benefit, when really they are purely acting in their own interests — and the interests of those financiers who pay the MPs to implement laws to hide their money: the UK people may not discover the truth for many years to come. The truth behind Brexit is something that sadly, will only be the topic of historical case studies, and not present day justice.

You are entirely, completely and ultimately FACTUALLY wrong about the EU parliament, the EU parliament has no powers over bills, economic manipulation or laws, the EU parliament also has no powers of election or votes on policy, bills, laws etc. the EU policy house has overall exclusive powers over laws, policy and legislation. the EU presidents are not elected nor are they assigned from a vote. Yes we can democratically vote for our MEP of choice, but that MEP has no powers of influence as the EU parliament has no powers of policy, law, economy etc.


EU parliament is used more as a sentiment index, auditors basically. MEP's can voice their opinions, form committees and become members of wider political groups. Only the EU policy houses can bring into law new policy, amend policy or remove policy. These policy houses are made up of full-time invite only employed staff that would be of similar equivalence to a peerage in the house of lords. the EU parliament has no powers to remove members from policy houses. If you do a law degree you'll learn a lot more about the secretive inner workings of the EU as law and politics somewhat overlap one another.

I personally feel it’s much better for the nationally elected EU Council and the nationally-yet-indirectly elected Council of the EU and EU Commission to hold a majority of the power, as it preserves the integrity of each one of the member states. If the EU Parliament were to gain a stronghold of power in the EU, and completely dominate the decision-making, then I fear the EU would become more of a single state than a varied mix of independent states. Up until relatively recently, the only common interest binding the EU 27 together was economic, with peace, co-operation and basic democratic and liberal ethos providing a foundation for unity. A recognition that harmony and solidarity would strengthen defence against certain foreign powers (*cough* Russia *cough*) was also a factor. However, it was always agreed that the sovereignty of the member states came first. To allow the EU Parliament (a body directly elected by hundreds of millions of people across 27 nations) to assume the majority of power is to disregard the diplomatic relationship between states and essentially merge 27 countries into a single, all-powerful state. I’d prefer to keep the relationships diplomatic, thanks. Ireland (where I’m from) would get trampled on in any international election, pitting our meagre 5 million people against Germany’s 80 million and France’s 65 million in a battle for resources, infrastructure and laws. In my opinion, the more professional an economic agreement between numerous cultures, languages and ethnicities is, the better.

I stopped giving credibility to this when it got to the point about the Commssion being the de facto government. Firstly it is the "Civil Service", not the government albeit that it behaves like a government (but unelected). Secondly, each country does not have a Commissioner. Each country nominates a Commissioner but as soon as he/she takes post then a solemn undertaking is made by each one in the following form of words, whereupon they cease in any way to be the representative of a country:

I solemnly undertake:
- to respect the Treaties and the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union in the fulfilment of all my duties;
- to be completely independent in carrying out my responsibilities, in the general interest of the Union;
- in the performance of my tasks, neither to seek nor to take instructions from any Government or from any other institution, body, office or entity;
- to refrain from any action incompatible with my duties or the performance of my tasks.
I formally note the obligation laid down under the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, by virtue of which each Member State is to respect this principle and is not to seek to influence Members of the Commission in the performance of their tasks.

I further undertake to respect, both during and after my term of office, the obligations arising therefrom, and in particular the duty to behave with integrity and discretion as regards the acceptance, after I have ceased to hold office, of certain appointments or benefits.

How close are we from a big change in this world ? @kurzgesagt

Well, if we vote, we vote for a preselected roster of people, who very often don't actually fulfil any of their election promises or stated political goals. Instead, more often than not, these people proceed to further the interests of big capital holders and not those of the people who elected them. I find it rather disappointing that Kurzgesagt is perpetuating the myth that our western political system is democratic. We are electing people who we don't know, based on promises that they, for the most part, don't fulfil. They are not held accountable for that either, maybe their political careers are over but that's about it. We have no control over the important decisions made in parliament or any of the other governing institutions. Yes, referendums are held but rarely. With blockchain technology, we could have had direct democracy 10 years ago. Every law, every governing decision could have been decided by all of us, collectively, not by people who we don't trust. That's a real democracy. Is it a good idea? Are people educated and responsible enough to make such important decisions? Maybe not but let's get one thing straight - until people aren't directly involved in voting in and changings laws, this system that we currently have in place will remain a form of technocracy.

It is not completely accurate to say that the Parliament having power means "your vote is powerful".  Not if "you" means "you as an individual" anyways.  The fundamental problem is that how much say you get is inversely proportional to the number of people who have a say.  "Your" vote is only about 1/8th as influential in the UK or France as it is in the entire EU.  So if someone's bottom line is "I want things MY way", and that is more important to you than how much "power" your top level political division wields, then local control which isn't getting second guessed by a power on high over which you have proportionately less say might be deemed preferable.

TBH, the EU looks like it was meant to take the best aspects of the USA but ended up looking more like the Soviet Union. The UK made the right choice to bail.

The reason the USA works is because there is a sense of unity there; we, as Americans, do have a lot of things in common, and things like the Constitution and the American Dream are things we can all get behind and support. Basically, we can agree on a lot of things, especially pertaining to what the laws should be. The EU, however, is composed of nations that have been killing each other for hundreds of years, and have lots of cultural differences between them. There is no real sense of unity, and they often have very different perspectives from one another. I don't see how trying to force a diverse group of nations to homogenize can be anything but tyranny.

I think there's a certain nobility in the desire to bring peace and prevent war, but as the saying goes, the road to Hell is paved with good intentions. I do think it is important to recognize the sovereignty of the individual nations and afford them a large degree of autonomy. This would also be more democratic, as it would place more control over a country in the hands of the voters within that country. Honestly, even in the US I'd rather see less power in the hands of the federal government and more power in the hands of local governments.

I also disagree that the affairs between states were "anarchy" and undemocratic before organizations like the United Nations and EU came along. When those countries became democratic, they gained the opportunity to vote for leaders who would or wouldn't go to war, and surprisingly powerful nations aren't always full of voters who are okay with conquering other nations and taking their stuff. This goes double if the profits of war are going to enrich the politicians rather than the people, as is often the case. Lots of voters have family serving in the military, and aren't too happy about seeing their sons, husbands, and fathers getting killed to enrich some douchbag sitting cozy in an office in the capital.

Although this video is well done, the claim that the EU is somehow democratic is very debatable.

The basic assumption is that national governments are perfect democracies but they are not.
National governments are deeply flawed representative systems where a lot of things get in the way of the "people will" : elected representatives are not accountable, candidates are often pre-selected through various tricks (biased polls, biased media overexposing the "good" candidates, legal barriers to be a candidate), there is no direct democracy, lobbies influencing politics, blank vote is useless, etc...
The EU doesn't offer anything to counter balance that and on the contrary worsen the problem by adding another layer of representation diluting even more the democratic legitimacy of the commission and the 2 councils.

Here are some important referendums where the results were against the EU agenda :

1992 Danish people voted against The Maastricht Treaty. They got it anyway.
2001 Irish people voted against The Nice Treaty. They got it anyway.
2005 French people voted against EU constitution. They got it anyway.
2005 Dutch people voted against the EU constitution. They got it anyway.
2008 Irish people voted against the Lisbon treaty (the rebranded EU constitution). They got it anyway.
2015 - Greek people voted against the Greek debt crisis bail out conditions. They got it anyway.
2016 - Dutch people voted against the Ukraine Association Agreement with the EU. They got it anyway.
2016 - British people voted against EU membership. They are still a member 3 years later.


Nice track record for a democratic institution, isn't it ?

This sounds like a familiar problem we constantly struggle with stateside! Here in the US there is constantly a power struggle and debate over state's rights, or rather whether or not the federal government or the states themselves should have more power to govern. As it stands right now, it's fairly balanced. A great example of this is the varying legality of cannabis products at the state level (some have legalized while others not), while the substance remains federally legal. In 99 percent of cases, the federal government does not intervene into the contradictory legality as it would create a massive states rights backlash, and would break the balance. This is a massive oversimplification of the US system, and trust me it has it's own nuances, but I think the EU could take our model as a reference, see what works here and what doesn't, and improve upon it to try to make the freest, most democratic, and most efficient unified governing body possible.

Anyhow, glad to see some activism in the name of better cohesion! And before anyone starts yelling about the civil war, NO, the American civil war was NOT faught over "states rights," that is southern revisionist history at it's finest. The Civil War was faught over concerns that President Lincoln would eliminate slavery, e.g., the southern way of life. Could you call that states rights... Yes, but it was kickstarted by the risk of losing slavery.

In the UK ( have not researched other EU countries) you do not vote for "people" in the EU elections you vote for parties. Voting is done by "region" and that "region" will not elect just one MEP, it will elect several using the d`Hondt system of proportional representation. .
e.g.Scotland is treated as one "region" and elects 7 MEP`s, but as a voter, you only get one vote. So, you cannot vote out most of the MEP`s as you did not vote for them in, in the first place, you have to rely on those that did vote for their party to not vote for them next time.

Most people would agree that every citizen voting on an issue is democracy in its purest form, but can also be indistinguishable from mob rule as I sure Socrates would attest to and can cause a tyranny of the majority, but also providing the largest number of people what they want. It is for such positives and negatives that an indecisive government will have a referendum.


But on the other hand, representative democracy can be gamed and more effectively so the more dials there are to turn while smoothing over the mob rule aspect of pure democracy. Take America for example wherein the federal elections, the electoral college votes how averages of the population in areas voted, which can lead to the popular candidate losing in close elections, but on the other hand, provides the minority rural citizens a louder voice. But on the other hand, the system is susceptible to be gamed and in some areas, voters which decent from the local majority can feel that their vote is meaningless due to how certain geographical voting lines have been carved out.


If provided with the option, and no fiscal detriments people would prefer to have more localized power and representation as opposed to a distance elite that you could never meet. Well, for the greater good, and for your continued fiscal prosperity of course.

The difference between democratic systems and pseudo-democratic systems is that a truly democratic system allows direct election of people based on the way citizens vote. A pseudo-democratic system instead opts to call itself a democracy and instead add just enough of an allowance for people to elect members/parties/leaders that they feel like it is a justified and fine democracy.

There is no spectrum of democratic-ness! Something either is, or is not democratic, so the question demands a yes or no answer, and that answer is emphatically no, it is not. To simplify this, let's ask "Who makes EU policy?" The answer is "The EU commission. Now ask "Is the EU commission democratic?" Being an appointed, and unelected body, the answer is obviously "No." Therefore we can conclude that the policies of the EU are not democratic because they are decided by unelected commissioners. Therefore, the EU is NOT a democratic institution. Whether those policies are then voted on by the elected representatives makes no difference, as they are only able to discuss and vote on what was dictated to them by those unelected commissioners. This would be like the house of lords deciding what the commons can debate, with the lords setting policy and dictating the function and form of any legislation, then instructing the commons to approve or disapprove it, and decide what colour and flavour it should be. Does THAT sound democratic to you? Soviet Russia had a similar system as this, with the duma being the EU parliament and the polit bureau being the EU commission, so was the soviet system "less democratic, but still democratic" as you claim the EU is?
I think you need to define the word "Democratic." A system by which decisions are made by elected representatives. EU decisions are not made by elected representatives. They merely approve or disapprove decisions made by unelected commissioners, so this is a weasel worded attempt to claim that the EU is "sort of" democratic. The EU is not a democratic institution and this video is conformist wishful thinking for those willing to forsake true democracy for the order and power of an autocratic system, who are willing to distort the truth to a ridiculous extent in order to convince others that this kind of "soft" anti-deomocratic dictatorship is perfectly acceptable. Democratic even!
Can the MEP's propose a different course of action? Can they disband the commission? Can a nation's MEP's choose to leave the EU? No? I think this video skillfully manages to overlook these crucial distinctions between true democratic institutions and dictatorial or autocratic systems such as the soviet union, the wermacht and the European union.

The biggest problem of the EU is missing awareness of the people, enforced by media. A lot of important decisions are being made on EU level without anyone reporting about it and thus no one being aware of it. When it then becomes national law, which is effectively only the detailed implementation, we see the large outcry. People are then being told that it's already decided on and cannot be changed. That is where the impression of the EU being undemocratic comes from.
However, if people become aware of these things sooner, during the EU-wide decision process, it can still be changed. This way it was with Article 11/13 of the copyright reform, but only because one very engaged Member of Parliament managed to be loud enough to bring this to the people's attention.

I'd say the biggest problem is that people are - understandably - dumb: they don't care about things they don't hear about anyways. That's understandable, because we all have busy lives and cannot spend half the day checking a thousand news sources. So in effect it requires media that properly report, not only what people want to hear, but especially what they don't want to hear.
Eventually, the biggest problem is thus media not reporting about what is going on in the EU institutions.


EDIT: Lobbying/corruption on EU level is also a massive issue. But it can only foster as well as it does, because no one is looking closely.

I think it's useful to compare the EU to the American federal system, because a lot of us will be familiar with that.

Imagine that Americans didn't have their President or Senator on the ballot. Instead, the senate is made up of the governors of the States, with a number of votes proportional to their population. This Governor's Association senate chooses the President. Now also imagine that there's no party system, such that a bill in Alabama has no effect on who gets elected in Michigan or Pennsylvania or indeed who gets to be President.

I think a lot of Americans would be unhappy with this, as a citizen in Montana would feel electorally irrelevant - and they'd have a point.

This system in particular allows a kind of power magnification you don't see in the US. Let's say you hold the balance of power in the German SDP (the ruling party). This lets you vote on behalf of Germany. Eastern Europe is integrated into the German manufacturing supply chain such that if the defy Germany they can expect to get rekt economically, such that commanding Germany's vote hands you Eastern Europe's votes as well. Germany plus Eastern Europe gives you de-facto power to nominate the European Commissioner and control the Executive of the EU. Having the Commission in your pocket lets you buy votes with patronage appointments and decide the legislative agenda, kneecapping the Parliament as a way of checking the power of the Executive. So de-facto, control of the SDP can be leveraged into control of all the chambers of the EU and once you have that you can shape EU policy in a way that solidifies your power within the SDP in Germany. You'd need a competent agent to pull this trick off but's there in the structure.

If I were voting in this election I'd insist on a European Commissioner subject to direct election by ranked ballot judged by the Schulze method. This would hand the institution more legitimacy and short-circuit some of the mechanisms I note above. If the EU isn't willing to do something like that I'd Brexit the hell out of there - Yanis Varoufakis and Mark Blyth note that the common currency without a fiscal union was deliberately designed to cause the Euro crisis as a way to strongarm the member states into permitting fiscal transfers even if voter don't like it. Any institution that manufactures an economic crisis in order to grab power is nucking futs. Good luck and Godspeed in the elections, EU citizens. I salute you! o7

I feel that this video would have been improved if the word "democratic" had been clearly defined. The video is clearly written from a Europeanist perspective but from a nationalist/regionalist perspective "democratic" means something very different. Democratic accountability comes into play in the EU at different levels, and how one feels about the nature of the accountability mechanism is flavored by what they believe the relevant polity is. If you're a Europeanist, you'd likely think that the EU Parliament needs greater power to act as the primary body of the EU, much as a parliament in a Member State would. If you're a nationalist, you're probably okay with the current state of affairs or want more power to rest with the Council and the Member State governments, since voting for them is how you'd see the EU being held to account. A regionalist would want more power to the Committee of the Regions and devolved power, for example. "Democracy" being left undefined leads to a lot of room for interpretation and it means different things to different people, especially when it comes to something as convoluted as the EU. I feel this video would have been more effective if it had been defined as well as given different interpretations of what that means.

There's a big factual error in this. There is abundant well documented and established evidence that centralized State authority, State power, and a State monopoly on violence of virtually any kind actually makes human society and politics less democratic and almost instantly more violent. Archaeology, anthropology, statistical analysis, sociology, and many other fields have shown that after a State and formal law backed by violence or imprisonment is formed it typically takes a century or two at the very most for incredibly unequal wealth distribution and a minority privileged ruling class with majority power over the State and its people to emerge.

In contrast stateless societies are generally far more democratic and egalitarian, with better human rights and less crime. They can also maintain those conditions for thousands of years. Even if they're settled societies with complex agriculture and advanced technology.

Centralization and the State are choices. Not inevitabilities.

I think there's two other points you really do have to examine if you're going to ask how the EU scores in terms of democracy.

First, there's the European Court of Justice and it's role in interpreting and enforcing EU law. A lot of criticism is often levelled at it for over interpreting EU law (particularly very carefully negotiated treaty articles) and adopting an approach that is skewed towards promoting further integration. If the ECJ does effectively extend laws then that's quite a big weight on the non-democratic side. It's quite hard to say for sure and can be complicated by different legal legacies in the member states (particularly RoI and (for now (sort of)) the UK which have common law rather than civil law systems) but it's definitely an important one to address.

Second, is how pro-active the European Parliament is in using it's powers, whether processes are abused and what happens when they are. The controversy around Martin Selmayr is worth examining for this.

It also may have been worth discussing whether democracy is appropriate, workable or desirable in a supra-national organisation.

This is just about how it is framed. For example, the video describes the EU council as an example of 'indirect democracy'. However, if you frame it another way, for instance, by asking the question: is the EU council answerable to the people? The answer is no. Sure, it is made up of heads of state, but each head of state is answerable only to their own citizens. The EU council as a 'body' simply can't operate in that way because there is no unified EU citizen to be answerable to. It operates intergovernmentally, so in affect whatever decision the EU council makes as a 'body' we the people simply cannot hold them to account.



So what this video frames as simply an example of 'indirect democracy' also means an institution that is answerable to no one. Just something to consider also.

5:10 Do you mean giving more power to EU institutions as a whole over member states, or giving more power to the European Parliament over let's say European Comission. Because these are completely different things. I know, you may say, but EC was selected based on member states representatives but
1) The point of criticque of a democratical deficit relies on the weirdly interconnected selections and responsibilities among EU institutions. Even if we let people selected by state representatives to decide, it can be seen as less democratic than if we let the state representatives to decide by themselves (and EU is by far not that simple).
2) There is an important conflict "freedom x democracy", (maybe, you could make a video on it, it is quite interesting). The point is that while voting looks like the only option in making global decisions, on some (personal) issues, global decisions should be never made. Democratical systems are hoping that this will be granted by wise enough majority, however looking and practical politics, this assumption is quite questionable. In EU, this is a level higher -- there is a difference between "the majority of states can outvote minority of states on issue X", or "representatives of every state can decide issue X on their own". Should we call the second option to be less democratic (but more free, anarchic, if you wish)?

It is pretty consistent to criticise EU for both, democratical deficit, and too much power over member states. Unfortunately in the video, it looks as if these things were complementary.

Part of the issue that often gets ignored when we discuss the European Union's democracy is that of Lobbying. Several pieces of research (Kluver, Braun and Beyers, 2015 gives a good overview of the research here) show that international corporations, and in fact many smaller interest groups now jump over national parliaments to lobby and instead put influence on the appointed members of the European Commission, who have far less scrutiny put upon them, and are far easier to get an impactful result. To hold them to account, voters essentially have to be investigative journalists in their own right, not only finding out who each commissioner is talking to and being influenced by, but also then try and lobby/influence their own government AND representatives to counter those interest groups, which is beyond the resources of most citizens. Lobbying is enough of a problem for democracy among nation-states, the EU inflates this problem, and arguably is the source for much of the discontent within the European union.

In short, the EU is democratic in the same way that countries like China and Turkey are - on paper (no pun intended) it seems like a democratic process is in place, but in reality the breakdown between the electorate and, in this case, the commission means that there is no ‘true’ democracy - only a bureaucratic system of low level public representation.

None of the voting public can vote specifically for a party for its leader to gain power, and none of the voting public can vote tactfully for a party on their policies (since they have none) like in say, the UK or USA - see the recent passing of Article 13 as an example of this; no one voted for or against a party that were themselves publicly for or against it - if the EU say it’s happening, it’s happening.

The idea behind the United States was basically all of this but with an organized start rather than chaotic gradual development. The methods are quite different, but the basic idea is the same. I wonder how the EU will handle federalism. The US saw a massive decline in federalism following the two World Wars, but hopefully the different languages, different national cultures, and a clearer public sense of the EU being a union and not a nation will strengthen federalism for the EU. Back when the US was founded, the understanding of the word "state" was that of a nation, fully capable of running itself, but now states in the US are, in the eyes of the people, reduced down to just provinces in favor of national laws, standards, and organization. Despite this appearance, however, states in the US are still functional as individual political entities, but not to the same degree that they once were.

One of the biggest critiques many Eurosceptics have about us in Scotland being both pro-EU and pro-Independence is that it’s somehow a contradiction.

However, I feel it’s not because they’re wrong, but because they don’t know to the full extent of the problems we have in the UK. Many of your problems with the EU is the problems we have with the UK, but tenfold. And unlike the EU, reform is abundantly clear not possible within the UK.

Each member state has their voice heard in the council and commission equally, regardless of population, stopping countries like Germant from having all the power. Each country, again regardless of size, can VETO legislation, opt-out policies and responsibilities and can altogether postpone requirements indefinitely without problem. And although the commission is elected indirectly, they’re at least held account by member state’s leaders and the parliament that gives them power. Each member state can hold the EU accountable for problems, and leave whenever they choose. Whilst all power lies with the EU member states giving devolution to the EU, which can essentially be revoked entirely if the EU fails it’s population, which so far it’s not nor seems to be in the near future, objectively.

None of this is true for the UK. Despite having a devolved government in Holyrood, it can be overruled, and has been multiple times, by Westminster without warning nor notice. England holds an overwhelming majority of the seats in Westminster, and can therefore unilaterally decide on laws that impact or overrule the other countries of the UK. There’s also a rule that if a law is considered to only affect England or impact majoritarily on England, that no non-English MP can vote. This wouldn’t be a problem if it was only English laws, but it’s not - it’s subjective. Meaning if the majority of MPs think the law affects England the most, which given there’s already a majority of English MPs, they can block non-English MPs from voting, even if the laws impact on Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland. This section has only been introduced under David Cameron, so is relatively recent and has only ever been used a handful of times, which given its potential, it can cause drastic democratic ramifications. Scotland also doesn’t have a VETO (can be overruled), can’t opt-out (like the bedroom tax) and must forwards its responsibilities (contributing £2.2bn in tax more than it receives in expenditure). The House of Lords is completely unelected, and doesn’t require being held accountable of those that appoint them, unlike the Commission - once a lord, always a lord essentially. The Conservative Candidate for North Perthshire in Scotland was made a Lord, despite LOSING the election to the SNP - meaning despite losing the vote, he was given a permanent voice in the House of Lords. Not to mention comparatively with the EU and the UK - the majority of laws and regulations are controlled by Holyrood if independent within the EU to the tone of around over 80%; versus being outside of the EU within the UK at the tone of less than 20%, which so far is decreasing by the day as devolved powers are being revoked. And to make it worse, we have to have permission given to us in order to leave, again from England with the majority of MPs; try telling Hungarians or Greeks that they no longer have a VETO, need Germany’s permission to leave, have their parliaments stripped of powers, made to pay more than they ever receive AND have no benefits of contributing more even if they do, and Germany, France & Italy are given enough seats to hold a majority over all other EU states out together; and then being told that despite voting for one thing, they must follow what Germany has voted on and is told it’s the will of the people of Hungary and Greece too because they willing voted to remain in the EU - see how quickly they want to leave.

Even the most Eurosceptic individuals must understand that your complaints and issues with the EU are the exact reasons why the UK is such a problem for us, but imagining those problems amplified and on steroids. And knowing that no matter how many compromises you propose and how many false promises they make, there’s no longer a possibility at reform. And to us, the EU isn’t perfect, by no means, the CFP is an example of this which although a good idea, was executed so poorly and needs reform; and exactly that, the EU can and has been reforming and evolving ever since it was created.

I believe in an independent Scotland within the EU, working with our European counterparts. Even if you’re eurosceptic, I hope you all can understand and even respect our reasons for wanting to leave the UK and remaining.

So, I know I'm not a European citizen (I live in the US), I think Europe essentially has two choices due to the mess of the EU currently established:
1: dissolve the EU and return everyone back to sovereign nations (but many people wouldn't want this as they're currently arguing with the UK over them leaving), or
2: restructure the entirety of the EU from the ground up, following a previously established system: Adopt the US Constitution as their own (changes are allowed but I don't think they should be at first).
The reason for this, is because it's already had 200+ years of experience actually functioning, plus, it protects everyone's rights and freedoms, especially in voting, and is set up in such a way, that, the representation is more fair and balanced (majority rules doesn't exist, and neither does minority rule, both groups are protected). Of course there are other things that should be adjusted within, such as: no bureaucratic systems (for some reason the US has bits of these around and they're undermining our representatives), hard, and enforced, term limits (so as to avoid "career politicians that insist on keeping their ass in their chair until they die, and damaging the government they're in/represent), no gerrymandering (for some reason that was allowable in our system and it's begun to create issues; and I haven't really seen much good come from this).
Appropriate adjustments should be made, representing that of the EU members, as of course the Constitution specifies the US (the names can be changed as necessary), and that certain aspects may not be as acceptable by the citizens of the EU nations.
I feel that a more protected republic that the US follows, would be very beneficial to the EU. This should also help to improve their economies overall, but, personally, I feel that returning to their sovereign states would be more beneficial than to remain part of a bigger, unwieldy, government. (Also, should any individual nation adopt the US Constitution as their own, would most likely benefit greatly from the freedoms and protections it establishes.)

Wow! Very educational. This is more similar to the US government than I thought. The US government was founded on a covenant between state and federal legislatures. Checks and balances were put into place so that one doesn’t become more powerful than the other. Unfortunately, like it says in the video, people became lazy in voting and the people who saw to take advantage of that did. Some checks and balances have been amended, causing a shift in government powers to favor federal. Despite what people think, the US government isn’t what the founding fathers envisioned it to be. A problem with democracy is that some people need to be more visionary and image how laws can influence future generations. Humans generally are impulsive and want things relatively instantaneous with little or no thought to the future — causing a ripple effect throughout the nation over time. The citizens of the US became annoyed by being denied what they saw as their rights and voted to remove the only safeguard to the future with the 17th amendment. Moral of the story: vote for local authorities. Even though you can’t vote for EVERYTHING, you still have indirect control over everything that’s going on. The more things you have the ability to vote for, the less you’ll honestly vote. The US can see who voted for what, too, but most people are too lazy to check it. Politicians aren’t always the most honest people in the world — fact checking is extremely important. Now our congress is voting for pointless things like whether or not we should declare Pi day as a national holiday (not a specific example, but they do vote for similar things) which drowns out the actual important information we need to form an appropriate opinion on the people we voted into power.

This is a great video but unfortunately you can't explain the complexity of the EU government with such a short video. The EU may have started with good intentions but it's been taken over by politicians, lobbyists and, by extension, corporations. Go watch CGP grey's video: Rules for Rulers for a good concise idea of why, even in a democracy, corruption is inevitable.


There are absolutely massive flaws in the system as it stands, those checks and balances that you mention are essentially a way to ensure career politicians (people who have never held a job outside of politics) are able to keep themselves in power.
For example: The EU commission can be dissolved by a vote of no confidence from the EU parliament but ONLY the president of the EU parliament can remove a member from the commission.


So basically only the person that was elected BY the majority of parliament has the power to remove any specific individual but if the majority of parliament agrees that the commission needs to be refreshed they only need a majority of them to agree anyway.


This means that positions will most likely change extremely slowly since the parliament can either:
1. go full scorched earth (not likely since that means some of the commissioners they DO want to keep would be removed)
or
2. hope that the next president they vote in will remove the commissioners that are causing problems.


To sum up: What at first glance seems like an extremely democratic way of ensuring that EU commission members (who hold office for life) can be removed when needed ends up being an extremely insidious way of ensuring that at worst only a few can be removed at a time.


It's also worth mentioning as other people have in the comments that the further removed politicians are from the people they're supposed to represent the harder it is for them to come to terms with the aftereffects of their new legislation for specific people.
Meaning: what works for them may not work for you but because it works for the majority or simply for the EU as a whole it doesn't matter.

This is very near to how the US government used to work. The Representatives in the House were elected by the people. The Senators were chosen by the state governments. The President was chosen by electors who were chosen by the states, and the states would poll their people to guide the electors (but the electors weren't necessarily beholden to that).

you mentioned only one of many points that indicate a dysfunctional democracy:



The judges of the highest courts are dependent on reelection by the commission, but function as even higher courts than the national constitutional courts. There are no balanced checks between these institutions.



The jurisdiction of the European courts is practically unlimited, but without a constitution.


The European courts can even practically create law as in a common law system, while the rest is organized as a roman law system and there are no checks by the parliament.



No separation between federal domains and central domains for the legislative; The centralized institutions can make laws about anything they like.



Failure of the fourth branch of government: the media. The politics within the councils are completely ignored; The politics in the commission and the parliament are underreported. There is no public discussion taking place. In the rare cases where a public discussion arises anyway it is ignored.


The parliament can not initiate laws (as mentioned in the video) but it can not initiate any other decisions either. It can not select a government, it can only veto the head of the government.


The formation and the assignment of power within the council of the European union is totally in-transparent. The decision making processes are in-transparent. yet, it is together with the commission the true legislative and the executive branch of the EU.

Brexit

As the founders of the US noted, there can be no effective centralized government over such a large swath of land, people and cultures. England and Spain had the same problems in the 1700's - they got too large and too many colonies to effectively govern and the same parties became tyrannized for policies that benefited others far, far away from their 'beds'.


This is what stirred the colonies' separatist movements even though a great number of 'common' people in what was to become the US had been scared to call for an outright separation and war with England. If you look at the then American congress' votes, you could see clearly that no majority was on board with this rebellion, Benjamin Franklin even voted against the initial declaration of independence in June of 1776.


The EU is in the same position right now, instead of emulating the US system of balance of power and separation between state and federal government, they went the colonist approach of France, Germany and England and even though 'local' governments are supposedly present and have influence on the process, they end up with effectively not a lot of power to overrule the central government which garners the local folks' dissent. But separating from such a power has its drawbacks, England pre-United States was responsible for protection and the majority of the trade, pulling that away from the Americas was a huge leap of faith.

The EU is a flawed system in that it mainly protects the interests of big business. Its democratic institutions are especially flawed, and by some considered to be little more than a fig leaf, since most decisions are made, and laws are passed, by the participating governments, and the EU parliament has very little power. I largely share this view, and think that the citizens of Europe should unite to replace this system with more democratic institutions. But I also believe that the little influence it gives citizens can be a political tool (albeit not a very powerful one) and that it should be used, without expecting too much of it, and without forgoing to push for democratic change and social improvements outside of this system.

The premise of giving parliament, and thus the direct popular vote, more power should probably be evaluated in light of the impact of the 17th amendment in the U.S., as we've been living with the impact of that very similar change for a century now. It looked good on paper, but the result has been the removal of a very important limit on Federal power. Our member states, for most purposes, have no say at all anymore in legislation that impacts them. About the only power remaining is their ability to reject federal funding in order to avoid the attached strings, and with no ability for state governments to maintain federal representation very few have the political will to do so, because they'll end up paying more than they get back.

This has led to the $20 Trillion in debt we have, $200 Trillion in projected unfunded future liabilities over the next 50 years, and a $3 Trillion a year deficit.

Many member states of the E.U. are already in that boat, a few are sinking because of it. Don't be stupid, learn from our screwup.

This video oversimplifies how the EU originated and misrepresents the original goal of the EU. It started with only Belgium, France, Italy, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, and West Germany being members of the European Economics Community (predecessor of the EU), which - as the name suggests - mostly dealt with economic cooperation (mostly regarding natural resources such as steel and coal). This was done in 1957 (Treaty of Rome) and since then more European nations have joined because of prosperity but throughout the years the EU has been given more and more control over sovereign countries (now I'm oversimplifying quite a bit). However, the founding of he EU was never about "ensuring peace" as this video puts it, that's what NATO is for.
