I have to say I think you guys should have done better with this one. There are several factual errors, and even worse, omissions that are very important to the structure, history and future of the EU.

You poke fun at the UN (fair enough), but fail to mention that both the League of Nations and the Inter-Parliamentary Union (IPN => LoN => UN) which came before it (important for context). All three of these institutions have failed to maintain peace, because they have never had and never will have any real power.

Likewise the claim that the EU was created to maintain peace and prosperity is not accurate.

The EU did not spring out of nowhere:

1949 the "Council of Europe" was formed

1950 the CoE becomes the "European Coal and Steel Community", consisting of Belgium, France, Germany, Italy, Luxembourg, and the Netherlands, (the founding members). This was partly caused by some political pressure from the USA regarding Steel - you could (perhaps should?) do an entire video on that one alone, and yes I am aware that we (UK) dropped the ball on that one - how things could have been different.

1957 the ECSC becomes the "European Economic Community" - and this is important because this is the organisation that most current members actually joined. It was not created for peace, but for economic power.

1987 the Single European Act is passed.

2007 the European Union was finally formed.

And the above is only a very very very high level overview, there are plenty of other events that led to the creation of the EU - and all of them are vital to understanding the EU, what it stands for (or doesn't). But to make the claim that it was created to maintain peace and prosperity is total codswallop. There are several conflicts that can be laid right at both the EEC and EU's feet - just like any other political power.

Also, is there any reason you left out EU directives in your video? They don't get voted on, we don't get to say YES or NO to those, nor do our representatives.

Yes the EU is democratic, when it wants to be. It can also be a power hungry oligarchy, when it wants to be. And your video just didn't have anywhere near enough depth, nor breadth, to truly cover the subject at hand - which is a shame as there are many parts of it that were bang on. Perhaps in the future you should not try to distil such a complex, and emotive, subject down into just 8 minutes.

Whether people want to believe this or not, the EU is very much the same to the US government, in terms of purpose. Take a bunch of independent sovereigns and unite them to make the collective better as a whole while still maintaining each "state's" sovereignty. This creates a problem though. How much power do the sovereign states get and which takes more precedence? The State's sovereignty or the main government? In the US that was decided through the war between the states and the head government took more or less full control over the states. With the EU that question was never truly settled, but for the majority of it's existence it has seemed to walk the fine line of complete control and state sovereignty quite well, but like all sovereign entities, they slowly try to achieve more and more power. It's actually something that has been an issue in the US for quite a while where the government has been slowly trying to gain more power over it's people and the states. This is why some have felt that Britain should leave the EU and why others from different EU countries have felt the same way. The EU in recent years has been slowly creeping into that "complete precedence" area and some believe that it wasn't what they signed up for so to speak and want to leave.


On the issue with your vote counting or not is kind of complex. The US government took the approach that the people's vote is very much important but at the same time, what legislation is established and who is elected into power can not be left up solely to the whims of the people and the "uneducated" majority. That is why there is the electoral college, both a house and a senate, and the Supreme court which people can thank Alexander Hamilton for this idea for. It is also why the president has veto powers over congress, mainly the house of representatives which are directly appointed by the people's vote. Now I'm no expert on how the EU is setup but I imagine that it is very similar to how the US government is set up in terms of things like having a senate and supreme court and an appointing group like an electoral college who are supposed to be the educated elite and are above the whims and rabble of the people and I imagine this is why some may feel that their vote doesn't matter all that much. In reality Alexander Hamilton was more or less correct though. Something as important as the head of state and major legislation can not be solely left up to the whims of the people. The biggest thing with the EU is that they make sure they do not overstep their bounds as throughout human history, the majority of major sovereigns crumbled because they took too much power over their states and the people.

1. For the main debate about if the EU is democratic lot, really depends on what you view as democratic. (Which in politics is a huge and very controversial debate). The debate is really if the EU is legitimate. And if Output legitimacy = legitimacy or if Input Legitimacy =Legitimacy. Or if voting and representation is what gives you legitimate, therefore the EU is not legitimate. For if Outcomes are good enough.

2.Furthermore the EU was designed to REMOVE democratic decisions from states in the economic and political sphere by following the enacts of Hayek's Interstate federalism. This was design to stop inference with the market, and limit the scope of democratic decisions which is fear to bring nationalism and unlimited democracy. (Bonefeld, 2017, Hayek, 1949; Streeck,2015) (This is but one argument of several, their are of course others. )


3. The debate about the EU is about who benefits and why. Larger Nations have more votes at the EC, for instance. The Eurozone heavily favors France and (especially) Germany due to the changes in exchange rate. As the EuroZone was suppose to complianst a few goals.
A make businesses more simple across the region
B Make the countries more economically equal


A has been achieved. B has not. In fact Germany for instance, due to the Euro being lower in value than the Deutshmark would be, means that they can produce high goods and low ends goods at competitive prices, therefore being able to compete in markets they should be. This have resulted in the PIG nations being less compeetive before the Euro than prevoiusly, which is a problem. The Euro alos crated bad incentives for poor nations, by creating a moral hazard where hey couls borrow at amounts lower than they should have. This was the main casue of the Euro-zone crisis in 2010. (Varoufakis, 2015)

Just pointing out that the assumption that democracy is a good thing is false. Read Rothbard and Hoppe!


“Under democracy, the incentive structure is systematically changed. Egalitarian sentiments and envy are given free reign. Everyone, not just the king, is now allowed to participate in the exploitation—via legislation or taxation—of everyone else. Everyone is free to express any confiscatory demands whatsoever. Nothing, no demand, is off limits. In Bastiat’s words, under democracy the State becomes the great fiction by which everyone seeks to live at the expense of everyone else. Every person and his personal property come within reach of and are up for grabs by everyone else.”
― Hans-Hermann Hoppe, A Short History of Man: Progress and Decline

The way the EU works is anti-democratic in many ways. One of the most prominent is that the European Parliament does not have powers to influence some of the most politically salient topics, at all. Many of these topics have started to be governed by the EU as a result of the member-states' governments signing laws at the EU-level and transferring powers to the EU. Consequently, these powers and laws can no longer be altered by a normal majority vote in any kind of parliament, as in order to change these laws or powers the countries need unanimity. This can lead to a situation where member states have agreed to sign a law about health-care, immigration or public security (three of the most politically salient topics) and the European Court of Justice interprets the law in a way that 27 of 28 member states dislike. They cannot change it, however, as 1 member state dóes like it and it does not want to budge to amend or nullify the law. The European Parliament only has powers to approve/amend laws about internal market law. This is one of many reasons why the EU is seeing a lot of pushback from lots of political parties across Europe and the next EP elections will mark a radical increase in votes for populist parties, entirely because of the way the EU functions. If you want to know more google "EU overconstitutionalization" and "EU executive federalism". Upvote so people can get more info on how the EU functions.

The answer to both is either "kind of" or "not really", depending on whether the glass is half full or half empty. Sure, there are democratic elements, and ultimately (although several layers down for most positions), all EU politicians are directly or indirectly democratically legitimised. But to call this state of affairs "democratic" misunderstands the point of democracy. The point of democracy is primarily to protect the people from the ruler by giving them control over their government. The EU fails at this task in several different ways.

1. Institutions
By far the most powerful EU institution, the European Commission, is made up of members sent there by the individual countries' governments, which in turn have formed from the representatives in parliament, which in turn were voted on in elections. Sure, you could say that this makes this democratic (after all, there was a vote involved at some point), but it obviously fails at giving the citizen control over the ruling body. The Commission is controlled by the rulers, not by the people, making it undemocratic.

2. Elections
The only truly democratically elected EU body is the parliament. However, restriction on how democratic it is still apply. For instance, there is no way to exert control over a politician from another country. This can be a problem, since individual MEPs can become quite powerful if they occupy an important position. Again, you could argue that this is kept in check by party politics which kind of can be controlled by the vote of the citizens, maybe...? But once again, this leaves the actual control firmly in the hands of the rulers, not the citizens.

3. Size
Size is always a problem for any democracy. The size of parliaments is pretty much constant, no matter how large the population they represent is, since it is limited more by the physical restrictions of how many people can talk to each other in a productive debate with limited space and time than by population size. So the larger a democratic system is, the more people are represented by each individual MP, which leads to misrepresentation of minority groups and poorer representation for everyone.

I didn't mention the many examples of simply redoing a referendum when a treaty was rejected by a member country, since these are not inherent flaws with the EU structure - but they still speak to a disregard for democratic decisions by at least some members of the EU institutions.

These undemocratic elements are understandable in the context of the history of the European Union, being originally designed as a trading union. Trading partners may have to coordinate regulations in order to facilitate trade, so they have to have a body that members delegate sovereignty to - but having every little decision be democratically legitimised in coordination with every member state would not really be feasible. This system is more reminiscent of a constant negotiation between sovereign countries rather than an actual government, so democracy is not really needed. However, the EU has departed from this function and is now drifting closer and closer towards a European superstate, regulating all kinds of things, spending a budget in the member states, with many EU politicians explicitly calling for further integration with the aim of forging one single nation out of the union. In this environment, when the EU really does have its own power and exerts a direct influence over its citizens, this general lack of democratic control and legitimacy is very relevant indeed.

the european union did not start in an attempt to create peace for its members, it started as the coal and steel union, in an attempt to promote trade between its members.
the EU is first and foremost a trade union, and has proven time and time again that the inner market is at the top of the pyramid in the EU, with the political union existing to support it.
this has lead to a highly bureaucratic union, where trade organisations have a much higher degree of direct influence on politics than in national parliaments, so much so that it is not uncommon for trade organisations to be co-authors of legislation proposals.
meanwhile the eu does as much as possible to obfuscate its inner workings from public view as possible, as was seen in particular with the TTIP and TISA negotiations, where parliament was at first not even allowed to view the agreement draft, and after public outrage was allowed to view it in a timespan much too short to gain meaningful understanding, while not being allowed to take notes, or reveal any of the information to the public.
following the collapse of those negotiations, the eu decided to host a new set of freetrade agreement negotiations with japan, this time not ratifying the agreement in parliament before passing it, despite it having many of the same mechanisms as the hated ttip and tisa agreements, specifically the renamed ISDS (investor state dispute system) should be mentioned here.

so when you ask if the eu is democratic, you're already asking a leading question, because yes we do get to vote for the politicians running it to a degree, but we dont get to choose who's on the ballot, so we have to choose the lesser evil to act without oversight in a supranational organization that dictates national policy.
the eu is democratic in the literal sense of the word, but to a degree it accomplishes the opposite of what people percieve as democracy.

The fact the EU Parliament can neither propose nor amend any laws essentially makes them a powerless rubber stamp. In the event (that happens never) that the MEPs refuse to rubber stamp something, there is nothing to stop the bureaucracy from ramming the same thing down over and over again. The MEPs can not affect any changes nor propose any reforms of any kind. The only tool they have is to withhold the rubber stamp and that is only ever going to come into play if the majority are Eurosceptics (rather than yes-men) that can threaten the EU with gridlock. Ironically or fittingly enough (depending on one's point of view) then that the only way to empower the Parliament and thus make the institution more democratic is to try to fill it with as many anti-EU MEPs as possible during the Euro-elections.

Ordinary people, really only have political influence at the local level. I'm from the United States. I used to live in New York City but now I live in a small town outside of New York City. We elect our own school board. If even one parent is unhappy with how the schools are being run, they can let the the entire electorate know about their complaints or ideas. An article in the local paper, and some campaigning at the train station, or at town event is all that it would take.

As a result, the schools are very well run and there is very little bureaucracy, waste or corruption. In the big city, it's a different matter, a majority of the money for education goes to the massive bureaucracy. It is nearly impossible to change bad policies made by the board. The NYC school system adopted a terrible math curriculum (constructivist math) that they held onto for more than ten years despite thousands of upset parents and drastically falling SAT scores. Only people who are very wealthy and powerful are able to move big government.

The EU definitely does make Europe more wasteful and less free. Saying that the EU helps prevent war comes down to a tautological argument. By definition, countries that are in partnership with each other, are less likely to go to war. But, the feelings of alliance and partnership come BEFORE countries cooperate with each other and create an international bureaucracy. They don't happen because an international bureaucracy was formed first, which then made hostile countries more friendly toward one another. If we look at how nations such as Hungry, Italy, and Greece are treated it's hard to argue that the EU is creating feelings of peace and love.

There's no doubt that the democratic representation in Europe is not increasing but, on the contrary, it is decreasing. One of the few examples of democracy in history was that of the ancient Athens, in which the people (the one who had the right to vote, in reality) could vote directly on each law. Those who decided to vote received compensation for the day's work lost. The ancient Greeks also knew our form of government, which they called Oligarchy. The oligarchs did not make unpopular decisions.. They only believed that the people did not have the skills to take part directly in the decision-making process. How were the oligarchs chosen? Based on their power, that is almost always based on their wealth. Of course, Athenian democracy was often criticized by the oligarchs. It was said that a simple expert orator was enough to bring the masses to even vote against the vital interests of the city. Surely, in part, they were right. Today we know very well that ours are not perfect democracies and that in part we live in oligarchies that counterbalance each other. We give an ideological value to simple tools for implementing the popular will. Is a government more "democratic"? Then it is more "good". Is it more "oligarchic"? Then it is more "bad". But i see that the choices taken by Europe have effectively ousted and humiliated the cradle of the concepts of "democracy": Greece. That those choices helped to destroy the middle classes in Spain. That those choices are squeezing the welfare state in northern Europe. That those choices have made the job more precarious in France. That Europe is raising funds to create an european army. All without uniforming the type of taxation or education among the individual Member States. And this is "bad". Europe is a mix of short circuits, imbalances and lobbying interests. The problem is that by now this kind of statements are labeled as populism. We are strongly conditioned and ideologized, and we don't participate anymore in any decision-making process, regardless of our vote. this is a idiocracy born of mediacracy.

The EU elections have very little to do with the EU democracy. The traditional argument for legitimacy has nothing to do with EU partliament, but rather authority vested through heads of state, who appoint councillors in the EU. It is said that this makes it democratic, because the heads of state are democratically elected (although not in every state is that both de jure and de facto the truth).

The EU itself is not very democratic, because it fails to provide proper accountability within its infrastructure to its people. its democracy is too remote from the voters, that it doesn't serve its purpose.



What this video glossess over - when it comes to the process of appointment - is a lie in itself, because it says " you vote for the government" the government is not voted in. The government is the executive and it is formed of ministers who are appointed, and a leader who is appointed by the head of state. In the UK that is the monarch. Even in countries where the head of state is democratically voted for, policy in such an institution is heavily shaped around the civil service and their own politics. The same way in which foreign policy is shaped around civil servant politics rather than voter politics.


Then what is glossed over the Institution above all other institutions in the EU. The ECJ has itself has had internal arguments about the extent of its law making ability, and how (many judges were of the view at the time), the ECJ was effectively making its own law as its own political institution rather than being impartial. (Hence we get the "principles of the EU" ontop of the TFEU and TEU, despite their being no such principles ever ratified by nation states).



In tying to be impartial its actually bias by not pointing out obvious truthes. Or stating any of the controversies.

The EU Parliament can reject or approve of proposals from the EU Commission, that is correct - but there's nothing stopping the Commission from repeating the vote ad nauseam. Once the vote is in, the Parliament can't repeal it in the future, and there is no incentive for any other branch of the EU to propose a vote on repealing said law.
Guys, face it, democracy not working.

The indirect democracy of the councils is a problem though: Heads of states often get elected with a minority vote, they just had the largest amount of votes (nationally). Small states are also over-represented. My two cents about the democracy of the EU:
1) Interesting how the problem before the Second World War was the "tiranny of the stongest" a.k.a. the concept of an Empire (The English one, the Napoleon one, the Sovietic one, The Spanish one...) and our solution is to create a Super State (sic.) What are the differences? The concept of modern nation post-war is a positive solution: a homogeneous population in a shared territory where social conflict and dialectics can take place it is a truly democratic structure for society. Now as an european I see a political and economic core, France and Germany, and the other are just colonies.


2)About peace: let's consider the "anti-war" aspect only. Solidarity and cooperation aside. EU did nothing to stop France or the UK in Libya. The most stable nation of the whole Africa is now a nobody's land and it has caused thousands of human tragedies in the failure to manage irregular migrants. Malta and specially Italy paid the price for it.
Intra-europe we have the example of the Kosovo War (1999, fairly recent) a non-sense war of aggression.


3)Political legitimation, how to deal with different topic and priority from all over the Union: a complete fiasco (they can't come up with a decent solution or they didn't want?).
It's a problem for many aspect:


- EU parliament is the only european politcal organ that we vote. We can vote only for our national parties, but they have to form an eurogroup within i think at least 7 country or they loose many parliamentary right. It's a comprimise of the comprimise. But now the total absurdity of the thing. The parliament has no legislative initiation power. Only the council of the vary EU Minister has it.
How does the Council work? We don't know, there are no documents about them freely available. So laws are decided from Ministers (imho just a few), but in the last ten years single nation like Greece or Italy haven't got the right to choose their Government via National Vote. I'm talk about M. Monti (European Commissioner) and L. Papademos (BCE) "Technical Government" in the 2011. Strong pressure from the BCE (an indipendent organism) even last year. There was a veto on the proposed Italian financial minister, P. Savona and our Republic President deny the formation of the new government after regular votation in March 2018 just for his view on economics. De facto our actual minister G. Tria is an imposed one. The same thing said M. Renzi ( the ex italian council president) about his financial minister P. Padoan (from OCSE) in 2015.

The fourth Nation in EU by GDP has no right to choose the most important Minister according to the national consensus. If there are pressure even in other country, we can say that the Financial Council (where decision are made) are out of the reach of the voters. Monti once said in an interview: "The European institutions have accepted the burden of unpopularity, being sheltered from the electoral process".



- 70% of the new Italian laws promulgated by the parliament come from European directives. A directive is not "as it is", a nation can make some changes to it, but always in a legislative framework that is pretty confusionary. Talking about the Article 13 is too easy. It has been discussed by third parties enough and has had a remarkable media coverage, thus creating a knowledge base on which to decide. What about all the other laws? Our national parliaments have difficult to stick with local laws and reforms because they have to study something who came from outside the country, understand if it's something that can be positive or negative and then start the usual legislative process. And many, many, many times are dangerous thing, like the Bail-In (BBRD).


- incompatibility between European treaties and national constitutions: a crucial aspect, but long to explain. Briefly we see many rights denied that our constitution took on after the defeat of fascism. One example is: we cannot pursue full employment (Article 4 of the Italian Constitution) because there is a threshold set by the ECB (this year 9%) which we cannot overcome. unemployment becomes a structural fact and no longer temporary.


In conclusion I think that this actual European Union is not democratic by design, and there are no way to "change it from the inside". However the next vote will matter, and I and I invite you all to vote because we need a democratic and controlled demolition with the restauration of the old European Community.

A Good Democracy:
1. Well publicised decision making .
2. Model understood by populace .
3. Representatives directly accountable to people - politicians motivated to enact will of the people .
4. Coherent public dialogue spanning all parts of the territory .
5. Decision makers can be removed .
6. Clear choices in elections .

EU falls short on all of these in my opinion.

1. Most people might only hear about most major bills at a late stage.
2. Who understands the whole model, or knows how all the parties work together?
3. Proportional representation allows politicians to hide behind a numbers game, rather than answer to one specific area.
4. Who knows the debates of other member states?
5. A member state would have to remove its entire government to change their representation to most of the the EU's institutions.
5b. Some leaders cannot even be removed in this way.
6. The only clear European manifestos which get through are anti-EU manifestos, as EU elections are secondary to national elections.

In the real conditions of life, in the economic process, in social relations, in their way of life, people became more and more unequal; dazzling luxury was accumulated at one pole, poverty and hopelessness at the other. The landlord, the laborer, the capitalist, the proletarian, the minister, the bootblack – all are equal as “citizens” and as “legislators.” The mystic equality of Christianity has taken one step down from the heavens in the shape of the “natural,” “legal” equality of democracy. The main issue I see coming up for the EU is the balance between state and union. Much in the way the US has to balance the power between state and federal legislation. We often aren't bothered to look up our local legislators before voting, we just have our party to vote for. I know because, I ask my people about candidates and, the only knowledgeable ones are people involved with a campaign, and I love politics and discussions there in. With any standard nation the larger it is the less your individual vote counts so, the US made a nation of mini nation's bound by the pride of Merica mostly.

There is a national military and, state military, national guard and coast guard. This way we ensure the sovereignty of the states and, we can quash tyranny and oppression from either entity. We need to be prepared for the potential of a fight just like in any disagreement the threat of violence ensures a level of civility despite frustration.

For a long time more and, more power has been ceded to the federal gov. and, it's causing some tension within the states. Those states are now doing more and, more extreme thing's to force change, like the abortion ban Alabama, and red flag weapon confiscation laws Colorado. There needs to be a balance between the state and fed or it will get worse. Outrage culture isn't helping at all either.

Sovereignty is very important and, the Federal/EU gov's should have some power but, not all of it. I don't know it her is a mirror in the EU to the US Congress where the Senate has a set amount of representatives and house that has representatives based on population but that's important too. If the EU aren't transparent, and careful, with what the EU wants to do, you'll see more Brexit situations.

I think at 28 there are too many members of the EU for it to be practical. In principal the idea of a common authority between members is a nice idea but in practice it doesn't seem to work so well when people don't agree on things. As already mentioned in the video, the members states often have very different priorities. I see it like trying to organise a meal at a resturant for 28 people who all have different dietry requirements and budgets. Sometimes not everything is available at the chosen resturant, sometimes its too expensive for one or more people, sometimes others can't make it to that resturant and even if you find a place where everyone can eat what they want at what they can afford then you sometimes find that people are still upset becuase they had to sit next to somebody eating a food they didn't like and at the end of the night everyone ends up arguing about who ate what and you find some people haven't even paid for what they did eat and have  gone home. Are there enough common threads between the member states to avoid constant back and forths over what should be simple decisions I wonder. And on that note off to eat, the food analogy has made me hungry.

Your bias is showing throughout, despite an admirable attempt to hide or nullify it. The EU parliament doesn't have much, if any "real" power. It has a veto right on legislation and commission formation and thats about it. The commission as such has to negotiate with them, on things they want through, should a vote fail. However granting veto power (which is limited anyway, after 3 revisions of proposed legislation), is not democratic, and when you take into account that the commission hold both the executive and legislative power, and are chosen by people that are at least twice removed from any vote made by the people, it is essentially technocratic. It gives the vernier of democracy, which slowly accumulating more and more power, giving it a vernier of legitimacy.

It is an illegitimate tyrannical attempt at utopianism, at the cost of European identity, diversity and as they showed in 2016 and onwards, even European extinction if necessary.

This video taught me nothing, though the 'We'll simplify massively and omit a lot of details' at 2:15 seems a fair summary. This isn't a video so much as a signpost to sources document.

While it discusses the components of the EU it omits the actions - which is like describing what a machine is meant to do instead of what a machine has actually done; to anyone practical mind who is less interested in whether a machine is meant to be safe and more interested in whether it maimed someone this is absolutely maddening, it is hearing someone argue that because something on the map, looking at the terrain isn't necessary. There's absolute clarity of this difference in things like aircraft design where the stakes are lift and death and the outcomes anything but abstract, but there seemingly isn't in matters of politics.

Events like the Nice treaty referendum rerun simply get argued away as 'oh you just don't understand how the EU works' (invariably by those who'd not gain from the result being accepted without the re-run), when what should be asked is if a rerun is a betrayal of principles that could legitimise any form of representative government. People don't object to the EU because they're ignorant of what the EU's (deliberately near-impossible to explain) structure is; they object to it because of what the EU does.

One major problem glided over here is the "voting out" of elected members. Unlike domestically, where we have single member districts, for EU elections we have lists. In the South East of England, where I live, there are actually 10 MEPs! If I wanted to "throw the rascals out" I would probably find that there isn't any way to do that. It also supposes that the decisions we don't like are being made by our representatives or by people who respond to our representatives. The largest power blocs in the parliament this year will almost certainly be the EPP and ALDE, meaning that we already know who will be commissioner (the agenda setter). No major political parties (only one seat currently) have UK parliamentarians as members. In other words, being members of the S&D (Labour) and the ECR (Conservatives) and the 5*/EFDD (UKIP/Brexit), they are always in opposition. This means that even if we did overcome the electoral formula and throw the rascals out, 95% of our representatives will consistently find themselves being in permanent opposition.
This kind of continental aggregation could therefore only work where voter cleavages were similar in each country. They are not, in fact, so the centre dominates the periphery both in legislative and democratic terms.

The main problem I have with the EU is that entire nations can be ignored.
Let's say a law passes that's supported by every single EU member (100% of the people support the law), except for Spain (100% of people oppose the law). The law would essentially cut the Spanish economy by 50%, while raising the economy of every other nation by 10%. If you compare the number of people supporting and opposing the law, this doesn't look so bad. About 450 million (assuming everyone is eligible to vote) support it, about 45 million oppose it. BUT, it's not just 45 million people spread across all of the EU. No, it's 45 million Spaniards being ignored.

6:25 i think this is a very important point for people to take home. Consider the following situation in a two party state (like most EU members):
Something bad happens while party A is in power, they blame the EU. Party B criticises A as they normally would, EU does not comment (or at least no one hears it) because this is a national election.
Something good happens, A now takes credit even if there was EU support (case in point, Italy's restoration of historical sites). B criticises A for not doing better.
In neither situation is the public really informed of the EU's influence on the situation, opposition parties want the attention to be on the governent where their criticism will affect the election, they don't care about how the EU looks and they know they'll get the same EU treatment regardless.
The EU commission (rightly) should not be interfering with national elections unless something egregious happens, but it would be good if the leaders of members states gave their two cents each.
There needs to be EU wide political debate and less scapegoating if we want a cohesive society to benefit from.

Honestly the EU just sounds like the US government. We have state laws, and sometimes state laws are contrary to federal law, or we have arguments therein. But as a whole, it's one large governing body which we all follow and pay taxes to, which generally makes our lives easier. Lots of people like to blame the federal government for everything that goes wrong, right around election time in particular, even though as pointed out in this video, many times these are the same people already involved in formulating federal law by being our house and senate representatives. Only in rare occasions do you see people thinking their states shouldn't be part of the US, like crazy Texas or Alaska secessionists (like Sarah Palin, who then ironically went on to claim how much she loved America when she wanted to be V.P. of it). America is also full of very diverse people and regions much like Europe, although I recognize that Europe probably has much more defined boundaries of its different peoples, which might create issue when voting on certain topics. Overall though, I think that the EU is probably a good thing for the countries of Europe, because by themselves, they are generally very small, which makes it hard to be an actor on the world stage.

If the EU's structure were slightly less complicated, and its members had a bit more control over voting for a central figure or figures who had the most influence, I think people would be more content with its operation. Here in America, if we aren't happy, we vote a different president. We know that it's congress which makes the most influence on our lives, and yet having the ability to change that central figurehead gives people a sense of satisfaction that their interests are being seen to.

1. The Union has clauses which strip the voting power of other member states, effectively turning a country into a vassal state. Not only that, but 3 eastern european countries have been threatened with such legislation over rather petty issues. This should raise major red flags for anyone who lives in eastern europe.

2. The EU breaks its own regulations over and over again in favour of certain countries. Case in point, the Nordstream 2 debacle, in which Romania has rightfully drawn attention to the fact that the project does not respect EU regulations, only to be ignored and then threatened with Article 7, which further reinforces my first point.

3. European parliamentarians have openly stated their desire to further centralize the union and dissolve each country's sovereignty (Juncker, Verhofstadt, Merkel). On top of it, the EU now boasts a project to build an army, which serves to further strengthen their grip on the union and give them the authority to be considered a super-state.

4. The European Union claims to be for diversity and inclusion, yet they punish those who deviate from the Brussels consensus (Poland, Romania, Hungary, Britain) while also eroding our national identity and replacing our cultures with """european culture""". Therefore, I'd say the current state of the EU is hypocritical to its fundamental creeds.

5. Regardless if it is democratic or not, how is the EU a legitimate institution? How can a european parliamentary who lives his career in Brussels claim to know what my country needs? Does a french MEP know about Poland's traditions and culture? What about all the other countries in the union? Do you trust romanian MEPs to dictate how your country should run? While it is true that the European Parliament can't directly propose legislation, and neither can the Council (in most cases IIRC), they can both request the European Commission to propose a law that does something they want, and they both have the power to amend and approve or reject laws once they are proposed. I think the idea here is that the Commission's bureaucracy is good at writing laws properly, which is difficult at an EU level. This does seem undemocratic, but it's not actually that different from how most countries work with the government proposing most of the laws; in countries like the UK, it is rare for laws that were not proposed by the government to succeed. There are also citizens' initiatives — basically giant EU-wide petitions — which is where the idea of getting rid of daylight savings time in the EU came from!

A few observations but first, I don't think the opposition to the EU is entirely on democratic grounds, it's on what it does and where it is going. However, even on democratic grounds it is way more shaky than this video suggests. For example, the appointment of the European Commission president is done typically through back room deals and negotiations involving pan-European political parties and others. It's not a transparent process and this has been criticized throughout the EU's history.


The president of the European Commission is the head of the executive body of the European Union, so yes it is a problem that this person has no "popular mandate", which is the democratic test. Jean Claude Juncker is no mere regulator or civil servant, his commission wields quite a large amount of power over the lives of more than half a billion people, and he has no popular mandate from even a constituency, which heads of national governments do.


Adding to that fact as mentioned in the video, the European Commission is the body that under normal procedure initiates legislation (rather than the actual legislative body, which is directly elected), it makes it even worse that the President of the commission has no popular mandate from any of the people. You kind of just gloss over this as if it isn't a problem in this video.


Another issue is where you said "if you don't like what the EU does on something like copyright, then you can look up how your representative voted and vote them out". This is true (though only every five years which is the MEPs election cycle, this length of time is too long IMO since the European Parliament is supposed to be the closest body to the people) and it is also true for national representatives. However, what are you chances of reversing policy by not voting for that MEP the next time around? They are EXTREMELY slim. Far more slim than electing a nation government and reversing policy.


And on that, the EU makes it so that even if the public was to essentially replace its whole government, that new government may be unable to reverse the policies of the old, which does to some degree diminish the power of your vote. Does it not? (see poland and the argument over migrant quotas for example)


Another issue is when things become a European competence, national representatives (who are endorsed more in national elections than MEPs are in European elections) can be very limited when it comes to aiding their constituents. Case in point, a British euroskeptic called Jacob Rees-Mogg was contacted by a constituent years ago seeking redress of grievance. The issue was that the man was a farmer, and a cow had died on his farm. He followed the procedure with paperwork and mailed it, reporting the animal had died and how etc. Because this happened at Christmas, the postal service was slow and the paperwork arrived late, and the farmer was fined.


This is a clear case where you should be able to contact your local rep and get this fine thrown out, because the man did nothing wrong, the failure was with the post office. Rees-Mogg sent a letter to the agriculture minister at the time, who refused to help. Rees-mogg was insistent, writing a second letter telling the minister that this man has done nothing wrong and this fine has to be thrown out, it's unfair. The response he got was essentially that this was an area of European competence, and he has to abide by EU rules and that if the UK failed to fine this man, then the UK itself would be reprimanded. So, Jacob Rees-Mogg, who represents a mostly rural area, could not help this farmer with this injustice even though he was his local elected MP with a popular mandate, and as his MP, he is the man that constituents are supposed to contact when seeking redress of grievance. Now of course people will say that maybe the MEP should be contacted, but actually the MEP can't do anything either since its technically the UK that has to enforce the fine. That's a good example of how the EU effectively suppressed one of this farmer's most important rights, the right to seek redress of grievance and have such a matter resolved by his local MP.


You also didn't address the democratic deficits in terms of referendums in the EU. Not just the phenomenon of the neverendum that the Irish have experienced a couple of times and so did the Dutch (at the hands of their pro-EU governments who didn't accept their decisions) but the fact that referendums are discouraged. Even for a major reform treaty, like the Lisbon Treaty, only the Irish voted on it (and rejected it). I remember hearing crazy positions from pro-EU politicians and bureaucrats after the Irish vote like "how can a couple of million people decide for 500 million?". I agree, so why didn't the other hundreds of millions get a chance to scrutinize and vote on the institutional, structural, legal etc. changes that Lisbon made to the existing EU treaties? It's actually even worse than that because in terms of content, it was essentially the European Constitution previously rejected only three years before by the French and Dutch by referendum, just repackaged and named as a treaty. The French and Dutch who rejected the EU Constitution, which in content was largely the same, were denied a chance to vote on Lisbon by their pro-EU governments.


I think it is telling that your video completely ignores referendums entirely because the track record of the EU is bad. I also don't want to hear the typical go to excuse of "but it was national governments who held the referendums more than once or ignored them". Yes, it was national politicians who are pro-EU who ran them again or ignored them. Effectively telling the people who vote against the EU that their vote doesn't count. Many of these politicians are part of pan-European political parties. It IS the EU rejecting referendum outcomes because of that fact, and I see no resistance from Brussels bureaucrats to this practice. Politicians like the EU because it is a potential source of employment. Lose in a national election? Run as an MEP! European Commissioners have lost elections in their own countries, rejected by the majority of their own voters, and then were appointed as Commissioners to effectively legislate for them anyway. This is why there is a such a divide between the public and the politicians / bureaucrats on the EU, the latter has a strong interest in keeping the EU going. A strong personal interest.


But I have gone on waaaay too long here so I'm sorry for the length of the comment but this video is made by people who are clearly pro-EU and trying to influence the upcoming elections. The details you left out were kind of important, and I also don't think the issue of "whether the EU is democratic or not" is the primary reason why euroskepticism is on the rise. People don't like what they see as a relentless push toward essentially federalism. You have EU politicians like Martin Schulz or Guy Verhofstadt talking opening about effectively turning the EU into a de facto country. EU militarization is now mainstream politics (being pushed for aggressively by people like Macron etc.) even though it was dismissed before the Brexit referendum in the UK for example, as a fantasy. That was only three years ago. There is also the lingering effects of the Euro which Brussels celebrated last year on its 20th birthday for the "prosperity" it brought Europe, seemingly in a very Soviet-like manner forgetting the hardship it brought to millions in the EU. There's also immigration, questions about global trade and whether the EU is using tariffs and single market regulations to push out competing products and raising costs on consumers etc. It's WAY more complicated than democracy.

This is a highly disingenuous video, as reinforced by the list of sources, almost all of which are FROM the EU. To say the EU is democratic because the EU says it's democratic is ridiculous tautology, and not an honest appraisal. The issue is not with the fundamental nature of the system; most voting systems work very well when you only look at the advantages and elect not to cover the drawbacks or major complaints against them. Let's look at the ACTUAL criticisms of the "democratic" EU:

Firstly, you swiftly ignore the fact that the heads and ministers of the member states who work in the ECouncil and the CotEU are NOT democratically elected; in almost all of the member states, the ministers are appointed by the head and people have literally no control over who that is. In many of the member states, even this head is not elected, and so saying that the people have "a say" in the decisions of the ECouncil and CotEU is extremely unfair. The EU claim to democratic legitimacy is based on grossly undemocratic institutions which themselves are almost always either bipartisan and thereby unrepresentative (e.g. the UK) by exclusion of views, or highly conflicted (e.g. German coalition) and thereby, again, unrepresentative by exclusion of top members of the other parties.

A second major criticism of the EU is the centralisation of power. Even if the EU were completely 100% voted in, this does nothing to address the systemic democratic injustices, classism, and cronyism which is present in the highly-powerful Western political systems (and I'm not saying it's better anywhere else in the world). Even the basic SYSTEM of how the EU should be run was never voted upon, but was created by the very elites that people are currently voting against all over the world (see Trump, Brexit party, right-wing rise through Europe, etc.).

Now, you touched on this last point briefly by saying that voters can "vote" on what they want the continued structure of the EU to look like... but that's not really the case, is it? What actually happens is that people are forced to vote for parties who represent a single specific issue, because the EU is so ridiculously huge, by lieu of the legislature being designed to cover literally every topic, that nobody can actually vote for structural changes without voting for various other reforms they may or may not want. This is the exact same issue with a two-party system, except, here, it's on an even larger scale, because voters have to balance the effects of EU legislation on the whole against the effect it has on their own country. In other words, voting reform is effectively impossible without also suffocating your own sovereignty. This is a nifty little trick of having an all-powerful supranational government.

Finally: you never address the fact that people literally do not have the time in the day to research all of the issues which are constantly being discussed in and about the EU. This is the same tactic that has been used, is being used, and will always be used, by state governments all over the world to pass legislation which the people do not actually want. There is no NEED for there to be a European government; it is a flight of fantasy which was designed with a purpose. It's not an institution founded of/by/for the people, it's a rich club of crony corporatists who want to create a European superstate -- you even state this in your video without ever mentioning that this is the MAIN reason people dislike the EU. Its very existence erodes national sovereignty, regardless of if their heads of state or ministers can vote in it.

You should take this video down and actually speak about the democratic concerns that people REALLY have with the EU, instead of pretending to ask a question and then answering with the standard EU laundry list of explanations.

Im not sure I agree with the question, or rather semantic of the question. I may be completely wrong, but to me, the fact many of the EU's institutions are run by the member states rather than the parliament doesnt make it any more or less "democratic". As you said yourself, democracy means it's run by the people. Cool, all european member states have democratic governments, elected in more or less well handled elections*. Thus, even if the entirety of the EU institutions were run by the member states, they'd still fall under the category of "democratic" - though very indirect. But presumably we're mostly fine with indirect democracy, where we elect representatives who do the actual decision making for us. It's how most countries are run. Having those representatives choose their own representatives one level above is just another layer of representative democracy. And just because you add a layer of representation doesnt make the system inherently undemocratic : in the US, no elector directly votes for the president, they choose super electors who do that. In Germany, one of our chambers of parliament is made up of people chosen by the states' governments, which are of course also elected one layer down. Also in Germany, we dont elect a president at all, rather it's the parties who do so - with the mandate of having been elected themselves in non-presidential elections previously. All of these procedures are considered democratic.
Oh, and for the record : Im not saying that this system or the examples I provided were perfect or even good systems to be kept necessarily. Especially the US presidential and the EU institution election systems are in dire need of a complete rework - BUT, Im disputing this idea that having them be chosen by elected representatives is undemocratic. It's less direct and thus more complex.



Also, this is the bottom line of many problems of the EU : not that it's undemocratic, but it seems that way. Let's face it, most people think about politics very rarely and dont understand the systems that rule them or the very elections they participate in. They also oftentimes have a very hazy view on the issues they are asked to decide on. That's also how one gets shitty results like the Brexit vote - yes, the british people are very euro-sceptic, but they were also very uninformed (generally and specifically). The point is, it'd be much better to restructure and simplify the european institutions. Give more power to the parliament, have some sort of elected "face" for the EU : a chancellor to the parliament, a directly or indirectly (by the parliament then) elected president, something like that. That way, people would know who is doing things in the EU, they could be talked to by those who take the decisions, that would be discussed more and maybe understood better. Also, it'd be easier to identify with a human group rather than the current rather lifeless entity that we got...





*The question of how well these elections are run, how good each system is and if some member states fail at some of the democracy-rules is quite another topic.

Good video, but one of the big omissions (and central to democracy) is accountability. People just dont care enough about EU politicians and MEPs, and the consequence of that is a lower standard of media scrutiny than what you find in national partliaments.

Take the MP expense scandal in the UK. The checks and balances of the system didnt stop MPs abusing it, but the media drew attention to it. If you think similar arent happening in the EU youre dreaming.. but do you ever hear anything about it? When was the last time you heard a scandal about an MEP or Commissioner? Doesnt it seem odd that scandals are a regular occurrence in national parliaments but comparatively absent in the EU? Is it because they arent there.. or because scrutiny is so comparatively limited/covered up/ ignored? If corruption and unaccountability are allowed to fester unchallenged it will only get worse. Thats terrible for democracy. Voting records, fiscal responsibility, ethical behaviour.. they are all risk.

The solution? Make people care more about the EU. That will cause the media to mention it more and engage with it more (selling newspapers). How do you make people care more? No clue.. im sure there are experts that do.

So basically, we've reached a paradox here. Eurosceptics claim that the EU has a "democratic deficit" (meaning it's undemocratic) and portrays it like some dictatorship when it is actually indirectly elected by national governments. If we make the EU more democratic by making more institutions directly elected, Eurosceptics will then claim the EU has too much power and it is a dictatorship.

Dishonestly you forget a few extremely important things.
For example that whenever a country votes too far "out of line" they simply get overruled, against the rules set by the EU, regardless.
For example referenda are overturned instantly.

Another extremely important thing is. Remember when the US became independant because of the "no taxation without representation" idea. The EU literally is all about taxation without representation; seats in the Parliament are solely based on population size, not on contribution --> This is the absolute biggest problem the EU has. Poor overpopulated nations keep voting for ridiculously and outright retarded plans and support eachothers plans... The countries that actually contribute all the money have practicly no say in what happens with their taxes...
(the greatest example of this problem is the recent situation where France managed to outlaw pulse fishing, a better and more sustainable way of fishing, simply cause they never invested in the equipment and their fishers couldnt compete anymore. To sum it all up: The EU is as democratic as people want it to be.
Unfortunately not many countries view democracy in the same way, everyone’s version of democracy is different.

Voters can be influenced and lied to by the media that is controlled by the governments and individuals that truly don’t have the people’s interests in mind but will pretend that they do.

A good example is Brexit, a government full of rich people that can get even richer should they make the UK leave the EU. The new tax laws that the EU planned to implement as of March 29th terrified the rich politicians of the UK government.

Of course you can’t force a country out of the EU, but by devising a cleverly schemed referendum and having the people vote for what the government want- no one can argue it was democratic. However, if you hire a company to monitor and target citizens’ social media (breaching their privacy) and prey upon them with ads filled with biased information- that is illegal and deceptive.

The EU isn’t perfect, however it can be changed from within by conducting honest democratic actions and making everyone’s voices heard. By letting corrupt government action take place you are forfeiting your democracy.

The parliament get's to elect the head of the commission only, in practise that's minimal to no influence.

All of this combined and considering the heads of state form a seperate institution that also excerts influence (though only that of the ruling coalition of a country) the parliament is fairly weak.

Short awnser, no real deciding influence, no your vote doesn't really matter.

It's the commission and powerful lobbies that run the show, only at less important subjects (read without any real impact as far as power and money goes) does the parliament in practise has a meaningful say.

I'm all in favour of Europe trading together, helping each other out with security and generally cooperating, but this kind of ruling on high and from a distance while implementing rules for the whole continent, is damaging when countries like the UK, Greece and Italy have vastly different needs and interests when compared to France and Germany or the Eastern European countries.

Nigel Farage wants the UK to leave the EU with a No-Deal brexit that would do severe economic damage to the UK. There may have to be a second referendum. If there is a No-Deal brexit then there will be a run on the GB pound(£) as the UK's external debt is US $ 8 Trillion. Honda has recently announced that it will close its car plant in Swindon by 2021. Thomas Cook, the world’s first holiday company, announced recently that they lost £1.5 Billion in the last 6 months due to brexit, BMW have now stated that if there is a No-Deal Brexit they will stop Mini Cars production in the UK. If there is a No-Deal Brexit that means that 80% of the UK’s exports to the EU are service products which can be blocked legally because there is no international legal protection for service products. That means that £200 Billion a year to the EU would be lost and an extra £300 Billion a year of service product export to the rest of the world. All countries needs loans and investment to function and if the UK does not want access to the Single Market that means they will lose their financial passport which will deny the UK to sell the service products to the EU. In October 2016 the UK external debt was US $ 9.5 Trillion. Over 2 years it has been reduced by nearly US $ 2 Trillion. All countries needs loans and investment to function and if the UK does not want access to the Single Market that means they will lose their financial passport which will deny the UK to sell the service products to the EU. To pay for foreign imports the UK must pay in US Dollars($), Euros, Chinese Yuan, and Gold Bullion, but NOT GB pounds(£). The UK will not be able to pay back their external debt of US $ 8 Trillion let alone service this debt, and all countries borrows hard currencies especially US Dollars($) for their economy to function smoothly.

If there is a No-Deal Brexit the World Trade Organisation(WTO) comes into force. The UK will then have to give a confidence and concession schedule whereby they list the amount of goods they are prepared to import per year. Then the rest of the members of WTO which about 164 countries will be given 3 months to object. But 20 countries which includes USA, Canada, Brazil, Russia, Australia, Argentina, and New Zealand within one hour will put their objections. Then they have to await for the WTO Adjudication for four years. In the meantime they will flood the UK’s economy with cheap food and cars. This will destroy both the the UK’s farming and car industry.

Britain 'will run out of fish and chips' under no deal Brexit . One of the nation’s favourite dishes could be ruined by a no-deal Brexit (GETTY). EU officials warned Britain that traditional fish and chips would be in shortage if a no deal Brexit took place. A treasured dish in the UK, fish and chip lovers would face a ‘crippling shortage’ of the beloved takeaway meal. If the UK left with a no deal Brexit, there would be importation blocks in play, plus EU boats would lose access to British waters and vice versa.


If the UK leaves without a deal, there will be no access to European waters (PA) . The EU wants the UK to agree to a short-term agreement, giving the EU fleet guaranteed access to British waters until 2019, which the Government has refused. British chip shops would not have enough white fish such as cod and haddock if the relationship broke down. The EU official said: “Currently the UK consumes more white fish than it catches in its waters and could catch in its waters. “Any fish the UK doesn’t catch it will have to import and that will become a trade issue.”.


A senior EU official claimed Brussels would demand Britain pay for a £39 billion Brexit bill, protect citizens’ rights and find a solution to the Irish border issue before reopening talks if no deal happens. On average, 21,000 tonnes of cod in if fished from Britain’s water. But the country imports 110,000 tonnes to keep up with demand. And all of those people universally serving their self-interest. For instance, the fact that politicians often indirectly have ties to corporations by either bribes, owning shares in it, their families owning shares in it, or many other different ways.

True enough, to some extent. But ALL of them hold one thing dearly. Their power. And they won't let anyone reduce it no matter what.

The central government isn't strong enough and all parties operate as individual countries, maintain the national pride and autonomy. You don't have school children being murdered at school en mass because of a powerful, greedy gun lobby has convinced people that the right to bear arms is more important than their right to live. I feel like we here in the US are moving so far backwards and becoming worse than we were (thanks to Trump and many other factors including the religious right, gun lobbies, money in politics etc..), and I worry when I hear about Brexit and xenophobic politicians coming to power in Europe (and across the world really) that you will soon slip backwards too. In general I'm pro EU or even pro something like a "United States of Europe". What I have a problem with, aside from that it grew too fast in my opinion, is the current situation and development of the EU. To me it seems to be ruled by power-hungry bureaucrats that finally see their chance to take the people out of the equation and rule like in ye olden days.


What I want is a clear commitment to the European People as the one and only sovereign of the EU, that all power comes from the Parliament and that the heads of member states or their representatives can only approve or disprove of laws proposed, debated and sent off by the Parliament. The Commission's sole job should be to assist the Parliament and to carry out its orders.
The EU doesn't have to be a direct democracy, an indirect democracy is perfectly fine. However, it should be much more direct than it is now.


Anyway, I'll go vote next Sunday, because only that'll show the people who want to make the EU into a authoritarian and technocratic mess that I didn't give up yet.
